{{Short description|American painter}} {{Infobox artist | honorific_prefix = | name = Harry Andrew Jackson | honorific_suffix = | image = <!-- just the pagename, without the File:/Image: prefix or [[brackets]] --> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = Harry Aaron Shapiro Jr. | birth_date = {{Birth date|1924|04|18}} | birth_place = [[Chicago]], Illinois, U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|2011|04|25|1924|04|18}} | death_place = [[Sheridan, Wyoming]], U.S. | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = American | education = | alma_mater = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | movement = {{Flatlist| * [[Abstract expressionism]] * [[Realism (arts)|realism]] }} | spouse = | awards = <!-- {{awd|award|year|title|role|name}} (optional) --> | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | module = }} '''Harry Andrew Jackson''' (April 18, 1924 – April 25, 2011), born '''Harry Aaron Shapiro Jr.''', was an American artist. He began his career as a Marine combat artist, then later worked in the [[Abstract expressionism|abstract expressionist]], [[Realism (arts)|realist]], and American western styles.
==Early life and military career== [[File:Livestock chicago 1947.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Union Stock Yards]], where Jackson worked in his mother's lunchroom. During his time in the [[meatpacking]] district, Jackson was fascinated by the cowboys he met there and developed an interest in the [[American frontier]] and [[Western (genre)|Western]] genre.]]
Harry Aaron Shapiro Jr. was born to Harry Shapiro and Ellen Jackson in [[Chicago]] on April 18, 1924.<ref name="MM">{{cite web|title=The Story of Harry Jackson|url=http://www.meeteetsemuseums.org/harry_jackson.pdf|publisher=Meeteetse Museum|accessdate=May 6, 2016|format=PDF}}</ref> His name was changed to Harry Andrew Jackson after his parents divorced.<ref name="Grimes">{{cite news|last=Grimes|first=William|title=Harry Jackson, Artist Who Captured the West, Dies at 87|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/28/arts/design/harry-jackson-artist-who-captured-the-west-dies-at-87.html?_r=0|accessdate=May 5, 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|date=April 28, 2011}} Note: A version of this article appears in print on April 30, 2011, on page D7 of the New York edition with the headline: "Harry Jackson, 87, Artist of American West".</ref><ref name="McLellan">{{cite news|last=McLellan|first=Dennis|title=Harry Jackson dies at 87; Western artist created famed John Wayne sculpture|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/may/01/local/la-me-harry-jackson-20110501|accessdate=May 5, 2016|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=May 1, 2011|publisher=[[Tribune Publishing]]|issn=0458-3035|oclc=3638237}}</ref> As a child, Jackson sometimes skipped classes and wandered the streets of Chicago.<ref name="MM"/> He worked in his mother's lunchroom in the [[Union Stock Yards]]. Jackson liked the cowboys he met there and developed an interest in the [[American frontier]] and [[Western (genre)|Western]] genre starting at a young age. In his early teens, he began taking Saturday classes at the [[Art Institute of Chicago]] after his teacher recognized his artistic abilities and secured a scholarship on his behalf.<ref name="MM"/><ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="McLellan"/>
Inspired by a February 1937 photo spread in ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' about [[Wyoming]]'s cowboy lifestyle ("Winter Comes to a Wyoming Ranch"),<ref name="MM"/><ref name="Dies">{{cite news|title=Wyoming artist Harry Jackson dies at 87|url=http://trib.com/news/state-and-regional/wyoming-artist-harry-jackson-dies-at/article_f5db33f2-160b-59e6-90dc-0bf8a2745664.html|accessdate=May 6, 2016|work=[[Casper Star-Tribune]]|publisher=[[Lee Enterprises]]|date=April 27, 2011|first1=Kristy|last1=Gray|first2=Margaret|last2=Matray}}</ref> Jackson ran away from home in 1938, at fourteen years old. He hitchhiked to Wyoming, where he worked as a ranch hand in [[Cody, Wyoming|Cody]]. In 1938 he worked for Earl Martin at the Bradford Ranch on the North Fork,<ref name="MM"/> then with Cal Todd on the Pitchfork Ranch near [[Meeteetse, Wyoming|Meeteetse]] (which he later said was his "spiritual birthplace") in 1939.<ref name="McLellan"/><ref name="WPR">{{cite web|last=Schweizer|first=Micah|title=Future of Artist Harry Jackson's Work Uncertain|url=http://wyomingpublicmedia.org/post/future-artist-harry-jackson-s-work-uncertain|publisher=[[Wyoming Public Radio]]|accessdate=May 6, 2016|date=September 13, 2013}}</ref> He eventually became a [[cowboy]].<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="BBCW">{{cite web|title=Harry Jackson|url=https://centerofthewest.org/explore/western-art/research/harry-jackson/|publisher=[[Buffalo Bill Center of the West]]|accessdate=May 5, 2016}}</ref> Jackson also began sketching, according to ''[[The New York Times]]'', in the ways of [[Frederic Remington]].<ref name="Grimes"/> During each winter season between 1938 and 1942, he returned to Chicago to continue his art education.<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="BBCW"/>
In 1942, when he was eighteen years old, Jackson enlisted in the [[Marines]] during [[World War II]] and became a [[Sketch (drawing)|sketch]] artist for the Fifth Amphibious Corps.<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="McLellan"/><ref name="BBCW"/> He was wounded during the [[Battle of Tarawa]] in November 1943, and later in [[Saipan]].<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="McLellan"/> The injuries earned him two [[Purple Heart]]s and left Jackson suffering from [[epileptic seizure]]s, [[mood disorder]]s, and [[posttraumatic stress disorder]] for the rest of his life.<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="StorrowAugust">{{cite news|last=Storrow|first=Benjamin|title=What will become of Harry Jackson's life work?|url=http://trib.com/lifestyles/home-and-garden/what-will-become-of-harry-jackson-s-life-work/article_7e19337d-ca46-5b25-b29b-55d6236dc21d.html|accessdate=May 6, 2016|work=Casper Star-Tribune|date=August 26, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Webb">{{cite news|last=Webb|first=Jaci|title=Work of Wyoming artist Harry Jackson up for sale|url=http://billingsgazette.com/entertainment/work-of-wyoming-artist-harry-jackson-up-for-sale/article_e93a2eb3-5820-544d-94dd-469778091f53.html|accessdate=May 6, 2016|work=[[Billings Gazette]]|publisher=[[Lee Enterprises]]|date=April 24, 2014|issn=2372-868X}}</ref> In September 1944, Jackson returned to the United States and became the youngest ever Marine Corps [[War artist|combat artist]] at age twenty. He was stationed in [[Los Angeles]] and, in this role, drew and painted "[his] bloodiest close-combat experiences".<ref name="Grimes"/> Jackson was honorably [[Military discharge|discharged]] in October 1945. He spent the winter season at Pitchfork Ranch before relocating to New York in May 1946.<ref name="BBCW"/>
==Abstract expressionism to realism== [[File:Red, Yellow, and Blue (1951), Harry Jackson.jpg|thumb|''Red, Yellow, and Blue'' (1951)]] While in Los Angeles, Jackson's style was strongly influenced by [[Jackson Pollock]]'s painting ''The Moon-Woman Cuts the Circle'', which he said "shot the first crack of daylight into my blocked-off brain".<ref name="Grimes"/> Jackson recalled, "That single artwork caused me to relive (1943) Tarawa's bloody butchery; I knew that I had to meet Pollock face to face ASAP."<ref name="BBCW"/> He was also influenced by [[Wassily Kandinsky]]'s work.<ref name="BBCW"/>
During this "artistic conversion", Jackson moved to [[New York City|New York]],<ref name="MM"/><ref name="Webb"/> befriended Pollock, and began painting in the [[Abstract expressionism|abstract expressionist]] style.<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="McLellan"/> He gained a following after art critic [[Clement Greenberg]] and art historian [[Meyer Schapiro]] included Jackson in their "Talent 1950" exhibition at the Kootz Gallery.<ref name="Grimes"/> Greenberg said that Jackson produced "the best first show since Jackson Pollock's".<ref name="Webb"/> For the next few years, he exhibited work at the [[Tibor de Nagy Gallery]], which is closely affiliated with the second generation of abstract expressionism.<ref name="Grimes"/>
Jackson's travels to Europe in the early 1950s influenced him to become a [[Realism (arts)|realist]] artist instead of an abstract expressionist painter. In 1956, ''Life'' profiled him in an eight-page [[photo-essay]] called "Painter Striving to Find Himself: Harry Jackson Turns to the Hard Way", describing Jackson as an "American painter of surging talent and ambition".<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="Webb"/> Jackson moved back to Wyoming in 1970.<ref name="StorrowAugust"/><ref name="NPR">{{cite news|last=Schweizer|first=Micah|title=Sun May Set on the Collected Works of a Western Icon|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/12/14/250286312/sun-may-set-on-the-collected-works-of-a-western-icon|accessdate=May 6, 2016|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=December 14, 2013}}</ref> By the early 1980s, he was one of the highest-paid American artists.<ref name="McLellan"/>
Jackson later recalled of his time in New York and transition to realism: "After Cézanne a lot of artists made art for art's sake, and when I became an Abstract Expressionist in New York I was among them".<ref name="Saar">{{cite journal|last=Saar|first=Meghan|title=Judgment of Paris: Coeur d'Alene's auction of Harry Jackson's estate recalls a sobering moment for the artist as a collector.|journal=[[True West Magazine]]|date=October 4, 2011|url=http://www.truewestmagazine.com/judgment-of-paris-2/|accessdate=May 9, 2016}}</ref> He said the New York school was "too removed from man" and "did not speak to the people I was born and raised with. ... [[John Wayne]] spoke for these people ... he was a wonderful embodiment of the timeless strength of the rugged individualist, the one-man majority I believe in with my entire being."<ref name="Saar"/>
From the late 1990s to 2006, Jackson returned to painting. His work harkened back to his abstract expressionist experiments and military experiences, and also include "more peaceful, even transcendental registers of feeling" in the "Quartet" paintings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ucrossfoundation.org/files/2014/2687/9404/HarryJackson_8_panel.pdf|last=McConell|first=Gordon|date=2015|title=Well-Aimed Lightning: The Abstract Art of Harry Jackson|format=PDF|publisher=[[Ucross Foundation]]}}</ref>
==Works== [[File:The Range Burial (1963), Harry Jackson.jpg|thumb|left|''The Range Burial'' (1963)]] Among Jackson's combat artworks were ''Betio Beachhead'' (1944), ''Marine in Battle'' (1944), and ''Charging Under Fire'' (1945).<ref>{{cite web|title=Combat Art|url=http://www.harryjacksonstudios.com/works-of-art/combat-art/|publisher=Harry Jackson Studios|accessdate=May 11, 2016}}</ref> One of his first realist works was the large-scale painting ''The Italian Bar'' (1956),<ref name="Other">{{cite web|title=Other Paintings|url=http://www.harryjacksonstudios.com/works-of-art/other-paintings/|publisher=Harry Jackson Studios|accessdate=May 11, 2016}}</ref> which depicts a tavern and its patrons on [[Little Italy]]'s [[Mulberry Street (Manhattan)|Mulberry Street]].<ref name="Grimes"/> The work has been called "one of the most important portrait paintings in American 20th century art".<ref name="Webb"/> In 1958, he was commissioned by Ambassador [[Robert Douglas Coe]] and the [[Buffalo Bill Center of the West]]'s Whitney Gallery of Western Art, in Cody, to create the sequential paintings ''The Stampede'' (1965) and ''The Range Burial'' (1963), which were installed in 1965.<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="BBCW"/> Western influences are seen in these works, which depict a longhorn stampede dragging a cowboy off his horse, and his subsequent funeral.<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="WACC">{{cite web|title=A cowboy artist with roots in Courbet and Capone|url=http://www.williamstownart.org/artconservator/images/AC4.2.pdf|publisher=Williamstown Art Conservation Center|accessdate=May 9, 2016|work=Art Conservator|format=PDF}}</ref> Jackson dedicated ''The Range Burial'' to Pollock. Both works were loaned to the Atlanta Art Conservation Center in 2009 for conservation.<ref name="WACC"/> The {{Convert|10|x|21|ft|m|adj=on}} paintings were also executed as bronzes and [[Lithography|lithographs]].<ref name="Grimes"/> In the mid-1960s, Jackson created a portrait of [[Bob Dylan]] during a transitional time in the singer's career.<ref name="Webb"/>
In 1969, Jackson sculpted ''The Marshal'' for ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', which depicted Wayne as [[Rooster Cogburn (character)|Rooster Cogburn]] in the film ''[[True Grit (1969 film)|True Grit]]'', riding a horse and carrying a rifle.<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="McLellan"/> Following Wayne's death in 1979, Jackson was commissioned by [[Great Western Bank (1919–97)|Great Western Savings & Loan]] to create a sculpture of Wayne, who had appeared in a series of commercials for the company during his last two years, for the Great Western Savings & Loan building (now Flynt Building) along [[Wilshire Boulevard]] in [[Beverly Hills, California]].<ref name="McLellan"/> Prior to ''The Horseman''{{'s}} debut, the Beverly Hills Architectural Commission requested multiple changes, including the removal of multicolored paint and a motor in its base that would have slowly rotated the sculpture.<ref name="McLellan"/><ref name="Braund">{{cite journal|last1=Braund|first1=Simon|title=The Last Boy Scout|journal=[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]|date=November 1, 2008|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1903462991.html|accessdate=May 11, 2006}}</ref> The {{Convert|21|ft|m|adj=on}}, {{Convert|6|t|kg|adj=on}} [[bronze sculpture]] was dedicated in 1984.<ref name="McLellan"/> In 1980, the monumental sculpture Sacagawea was dedicated at the Buffalo Bill Center of the West.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://centerofthewest.org/2015/08/18/sculpture-guide-sacagawea/|title=Sculpture Guide: Sacagawea|publisher=Buffalo Bill Center of the West|accessdate=June 15, 2016}}</ref>
Between April 2005 and May 2006, Jackson completed the first six of his "Quartet" paintings, which he said "indicate the blissfully liberating spirit of Kandinsky and Pollock".<ref name="BBCW"/> The first four are featured in the film ''Harry Jackson Talks About Art'', which is about the intersection of Jackson's abstract and realist work. His bronze sculpture ''Sacajawea Modified II'' (2005) was the featured work for the 2006 Buffalo Bill Art Show and Sale, for which Jackson was named "Honored Artist".<ref name="BBCW"/>
In 2007, [[California State University, Northridge]] opened the Washington Mutual Gallery in the campus' Redwood Hall, showcasing thirty Jackson sculptures on permanent display. The collection's bronzes, valued at $740,000, depict cowboys, Native Americans, and early Western life, and were donated by [[Washington Mutual]] in 2006 to commemorate the "profound role Cal State Northridge plays in the cultural life of the region".<ref>{{cite news|title=Briefly|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-9093483.html|accessdate=May 11, 2016|work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]|date=April 12, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Washington Mutual Bank Gives Harry Jackson Art Collection to Cal State Northridge|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1125879951.html|publisher=United States Federal News Service ([[HT Media]])|accessdate=May 11, 2016|date=April 10, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=California State University, Northridge Opens Washington Mutual Gallery, New Home for Harry Jackson Bronze Collection|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1207745981.html|publisher=United States Federal News Service (HT Media)|accessdate=May 11, 2016|date=January 31, 2007}}</ref>
==Personal and later life== [[File:Joan Baez Bob Dylan.jpg|thumb|right|[[Joan Baez]] and [[Bob Dylan]] in 1963. Jackson performed with both at [[Carnegie Hall]] and, in the mid-1960s, created a portrait of Dylan during a transitional time in the singer's career.]]
Jackson did some acting on Hollywood radio and recorded songs he learned at Pitchfork Ranch for [[Folkways Records]] during the 1950s.<ref name="WPR"/><ref name="NPR"/><ref name="AllMusic">{{cite web|title=Harry Jackson: Biography|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/harry-jackson-mn0002116113|website=[[AllMusic]]|publisher=[[All Media Network]]|accessdate=May 6, 2016|first=Bruce|last=Eder}}</ref> His album ''The Cowboy: His Songs, Ballads and Brag Talk'' was released in 1959.<ref name=iTunes>{{cite web|title=The Cowboy: His Songs, Ballads and Brag Talk|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/cowboy-his-songs-ballads-brag/id157031506|publisher=[[iTunes Store]]|accessdate=May 9, 2016}}</ref> He recorded for [[Columbia Records]] in New York during the 1960s,<ref name="AllMusic"/> and even sang at [[Carnegie Hall]] with Dylan and [[Joan Baez]],<ref name="WPR"/><ref name="StorrowAugust"/> and [[Pete Seeger]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rhoten|first1=Josh|title=February 9, 2014|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-35678162.html|accessdate=May 11, 2016|work=[[Wyoming Tribune Eagle]]|date=February 9, 2014}}</ref> His repertory included songs like "The Pot Wrassler" and "[[Streets of Laredo (song)|Streets of Laredo]]", and were "all sung in an authentic, unadorned style far removed from popular music or the folk-pop of the period".<ref name="AllMusic"/>
In 1954, Jackson purchased a series of 1860 sketches by [[Paul Cézanne]] for $80 from someone at [[Aix-en-Provence]] who claimed that his father was the artist's caretaker. Jackson tried to sell them in 1962, but they were deemed stolen and confiscated after a [[Louvre]] seal was found during the authentication process. He fought for ownership of the sketches for five years and withdrew his claim in 1967. He said, "I was mad. Darn mad. But now I have come full circle and am returning the drawings, which is what I would have done immediately if the FBI had not taken the drawings and I had just been notified by Rewald."<ref name="Saar"/>
He began a private journal, which eventually grew to more than 100 volumes, in March 1945.<ref name="BBCW"/> Jackson's journal entry about meeting Pollock read:
{{quote|On Monday Oct 11, 1948, I finally met Jackson Pollock who became my friend and mentor who deeply influenced my entire life's work to this day. A few days after Jack and I bonded, my wild White Figure painting volcanically erupted from my sealed-off blacked-out mind. It was far too revealing, so I didn't show it to anyone until my exhaustive Retrospective at the University of Wyoming Art Museum in 1987.<ref name="BBCW"/>}}
[[File:John Wayne - 1961.JPG|thumb|left|Publicity photo of [[John Wayne]] for the 1961 film ''[[The Comancheros (film)|The Comancheros]]''. Jackson's sculpture ''The Marshal'' was created in 1969 for ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' and depicted Wayne as [[Rooster Cogburn (character)|Rooster Cogburn]] in the film ''[[True Grit (1969 film)|True Grit]]''. The two were friends during Wayne's final decade of life.]]
According to some sources, Jackson was married and divorced as many as six times.<ref name="Storrow"/> However, his official biography on the Harry Jackson Studios website states that he was married four times.<ref name="Bio">{{cite web|title=Harry Jackson Bio|url=http://www.harryjacksonstudios.com/harry-jackson-bio/|publisher=Harry Jackson Studios|accessdate=May 9, 2016}}</ref> One of his marriages was to abstract expressionist painter [[Grace Hartigan]], which lasted for a year.<ref name="Storrow"/>
After leaving New York, Jackson lived in Wyoming and [[Camaiore]], Italy, where he had a foundry and studio.<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="McLellan"/> According to the Buffalo Bill Center of the West, Jackson also resided in Meeteetse and Lost Cabin, Wyoming in his lifetime.<ref name="BBCW"/>
Jackson was reportedly "fiercely loyal to his friends" and often worked with others he deemed were "fellow mavericks".<ref name="Webb"/> He and John Wayne became friends in the final decade of Wayne's life.<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="McLellan"/> In addition to the brain injuries inflicted during his military service, he was diagnosed with [[narcissistic personality disorder]] and, according to his son, "treated everyday like a life and death battle".<ref name="StorrowAugust"/>
==Death and legacy== Jackson died at the Veterans Health Administration's medical center in Sheridan on April 25, 2011 at the age of 87, following several health issues during his final year.<ref name="Dies"/><ref name="BBCW"/> He was survived by three sons, two daughters, and four grandchildren.<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="McLellan"/> His oldest son,<ref name="StorrowAugust"/> Matt, manages the Jackson collection and estate in Cody.<ref name="Webb"/><ref name="NatGeo"/> In August 2013, the [[Wyoming Arts Council]] began developing a plan to preserve Jackson's work, which included the participation of the Buffalo Bill Center of the West, Nicolaysen Art Museum, and the University of Wyoming Art Museum.<ref name="StorrowAugust"/> Matt continued efforts to fundraise the $5 million needed to maintain the collection and found an institution, and he also organized traveling exhibits to showcase his father's work.<ref name="WPR"/><ref name="NPR"/> His goal was to keep the collection together, preferably within Wyoming,<ref name="StorrowAugust"/> but the trust had to begin selling pieces after no offers to fund the preservation of the entire collection were received.<ref name="WPR"/><ref name="Storrow">{{cite news|last=Storrow|first=Benjamin|title=2013 Look Back: What will become of Harry Jackson's art?|url=http://trib.com/news/state-and-regional/look-back-what-will-become-of-harry-jackson-s-art/article_d623cc55-27c7-543f-8c34-fe81837e4b39.html|accessdate=May 6, 2016|work=Casper Star-Tribune|date=December 31, 2013}}</ref> Reno's Coeur d'Alene Art Auction sold a series of his artworks on July 23, 2011.<ref name="Saar"/>
In 2014, after spending three years assembling and surveying their father's work following his death, Jackson's children searched for an institution to house the collection of more than 5,000 drawings, paintings, and sculptures Jackson had stored and displayed in his home in Cody and foundry in Italy.<ref name="Webb"/> One of his sons, who serves as trustee of the Harry Jackson Trust, said: "Harry Jackson's body of work can only be fully examined now that he has passed away and stopped creating. The collection tells the full story of an unparalleled artist's life, and it's unlike any other ... [The collection is] something the art world has never had the chance to fully examine, and now that he is absent, we're learning so much more about his invaluable contribution to American art."<ref name="Webb"/> The collection also included brushes, home videos, photographs, props, reference books, tools, Jackson's business and personal records, and more than 100 volumes of his journals.<ref name="Webb"/>
The Nicolaysen Art Museum exhibited ''The Big Picture: A Look at the Life and Art of Harry Jackson'' from May to August, 2014.<ref name="Nicolaysen">{{cite web|title=Past Exhibitions|url=http://www.thenic.org/index.php?/exhibitions/C3|publisher=Nicolaysen Art Museum|accessdate=May 9, 2016}}</ref> In 2015, Harry Jackson Studios exhibited ''Betio: Light and War'', which consists of 56 paintings, for the first time and in conjunction with the Buffalo Bill Center of the West "Rendezvous Royale" fundraiser. Artist and critic Gordon McConnell, who was a curator for the [[Yellowstone Art Museum]], described the exhibit as a "monumental masterpiece" that "deserves a place among the important paintings of our time."<ref name="Enterprise">{{cite news|title=Harry Jackson art on display during Rendezvous|url=http://www.codyenterprise.com/news/local/article_762faf62-5ca0-11e5-b37e-ef84b52155cd.html|accessdate=May 6, 2016|work=[[Cody Enterprise]]|date=September 16, 2015}}</ref> Also showcased were sculptures formerly stored at Jackson's foundry in Italy, along with dozens of other drawings, paintings, and sculptures.<ref name="Enterprise"/>
[[File:Buffalo Bill Historical Center 001.JPG|thumb|right|The [[Buffalo Bill Center of the West]], which commissioned Jackson to create the sequential paintings ''The Stampede'' and ''The Range Burial'' in the 1960s, houses the largest museum collection of the artist's work in the United States.]]
Institutions with works by Jackson include the [[American Museum in Britain]], [[Amon Carter Museum of American Art]], [[Denver Art Museum]], [[Gilcrease Museum]], [[Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum]], [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]],<ref name="Met">{{cite web|title=The Marshal (John Wayne as Rooster Cogburn)|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/484560|publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]|accessdate=May 6, 2016}}</ref> [[Ronald Reagan Presidential Library]], and [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]].<ref name="Dies"/><ref name="BBCW"/> His work is in the private collections of the [[House of Saud]], Italian Federal Government, [[Queen Elizabeth II]], and the Vatican.<ref name="BBCW"/><ref name="NatGeo"/> The Buffalo Bill Center of the West houses the largest museum collection of Jackson's work in the United States.<ref name="McLellan"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Western artist Harry Jackson dies at age 87|url=https://www.victoriaadvocate.com/news/2011/apr/27/bc-us-obit-harry-jackson/|accessdate=May 9, 2016|work=[[The Victoria Advocate]]|publisher=Victoria Advocate Publishing|date=April 27, 2011}}</ref> Other Wyoming institutions with works by Jackson include the Meeteetse Museum,<ref name="MM"/> [[University of Wyoming]], and the [[Wyoming State Museum]], among other public and private collections.<ref name="BBCW"/>
==Reception== Jackson became most known for his abstract art and paintings and bronze sculptures of cowboys and Indians.<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="BBCW"/> He has also been credited for mastering the [[Lost-wax casting|lost-wax]] method of bronze casting and reviving [[polychrome sculpture]].<ref name="Dies"/>
In 1980, ''[[The New York Times]]'' art critic [[Hilton Kramer]] said that Jackson's Western-inspired works were "unlike any other in the recent history of American art".<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="StorrowAugust"/> Furthermore, Kramer said that the evolution of Jackson's style "has turned a well-known and highly praised but penurious young artist into one of the wealthiest 'unknown' artists in America — an artist unknown, that is, to the art world where his first reputation was made 30 years ago."<ref name="Grimes"/> Jackson received the Wyoming Arts Council Governor's Arts Award in 1990.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cody's Harry Jackson got his start as Marine combat artist|url=http://wyoarts.state.wy.us/codys-harry-jackson-got-his-start-as-marine-combat-artist/|accessdate=May 9, 2016|date=July 16, 2010|publisher=[[Wyoming Arts Council]]}}</ref>
In Jackson's obituary, ''The New York Times'' described him as an "artist who captured the West".<ref name="Webb"/> In 2013, ''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]'' contributor Jordan Carlton Schaul described Jackson as the "preeminent Western artist of his time" and "one of the most distinguished American sculptors and painters in history".<ref name="NatGeo">{{cite journal|last=Schaul|first=Jordan Carlton|title=Legacy of Harry Jackson: the Preeminent Sculptor & Painter of the Wild West|journal=[[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]]|date=September 23, 2013|url=http://voices.nationalgeographic.com/2013/09/23/legacy-of-harry-jackson-the-preeminent-sculptor-painter-of-the-wild-west/|accessdate=May 5, 2016}}</ref>
[[Lyndon Johnson]], [[Gerald Ford]], and [[Ronald Reagan]] each appreciated and displayed Jackson's works, and selected his sculptures as gifts to heads of state.<ref name="McLellan"/><ref name="Webb"/> In 1976, Ford gave [[Queen Elizabeth II]] a sculpture called ''Two Champs'',<ref>{{cite news|title=All the Presidents, Ma'am; A Debut for Obamas but Smiling Queen Has Seen US First Families Come and Go|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-197078694.html|accessdate=May 11, 2016|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|date=April 4, 2009|location=London|oclc=223228477}}</ref> which depicts [[Clayton Danks]] hanging onto Steamboat, the stallion from [[Bucking Horse and Rider]] seen on [[Vehicle registration plates of Wyoming|Wyoming's vehicle registration plates]], to celebrate the [[United States Bicentennial]].<ref name="StorrowAugust"/> Reagan kept eight bronzes in the [[White House]].<ref name="Storrow"/>
==Selected list of works== [[File:The Marshal, Painted (1970), Harry Jackson.jpg|thumb|''The Marshal, Painted'' (1970)]]
===Albums=== * ''The Cowboy: His Songs, Ballads and Brag Talk'' (1959,<ref name="iTunes"/> 1965),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.smithsonianfolkways.org/liner_notes/folkways/FW05723.pdf|publisher=[[Smithsonian Institution]]|accessdate=May 9, 2016|title=Harry Jackson: The Cowboy: His Songs, Ballads and Brag Talk}}</ref> Folkways Recordings
===Drawings=== * ''Tarawa-Betio'' (1940s), part of the collection of the [[National Museum of the Marine Corps]]<ref name="Storrow"/>
===Exhibitions=== * ''Well-Aimed Lighting: The Abstract Art of Harry Jackson'' (1953), Ucross Foundation Art Gallery (2012)<ref name="Ucross">{{cite web|title=Ucross Foundation to Exhibit Work of Harry Jackson|url=http://www.sheridanmedia.com/news/ucross-foundation-exhibit-work-harry-jackson76740|publisher=Sheridan Media|accessdate=May 9, 2016|date=February 7, 2015}}</ref> * ''The Big Picture: A Look at the Life and Art of Harry Jackson'' (2014), McMurry Gallery, Nicolaysen Art Museum<ref name="Nicolaysen"/> * ''Betio: Light and War'' (2015), consists of 56 canvases that together measure {{Convert|14|ft|m}} tall by nearly {{Convert|50|ft|m}} wide<ref name="Enterprise"/>
===Lithographs=== * ''The Range Burial'', based on his 1963 painting of the same name<ref name="Grimes"/> * ''The Stampede'', based on his 1965 painting of the same name<ref name="Grimes"/>
===Monotypes=== * "Random Monotypes", a series of 49 monotypes created by blotting dripped paint during the creation of ''La Fiesta'', ''Mexican Composition'', and ''Toro Rojo del Sol'' (1949)<ref name="AbstractExpressionism">{{cite web|title=Abstract Expressionism|url=http://www.harryjacksonstudios.com/works-of-art/abstract-expressionism/#!prettyPhoto|publisher=Harry Jackson Studios|accessdate=May 11, 2016}}</ref>
===Paintings=== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} * ''Cowboy Harry, Self Portrait at 12'' (1936)<ref name="Other"/> * ''Tarawa-Betio'' (1944), part of the collection of the National Museum of the Marine Corps<ref name="Grimes"/> * ''Untitled'' (1948), oil with sand on canvas<ref name="BBCW"/> * ''White Figure'' (1948), abstract expressionist<ref name="AbstractExpressionism"/> * ''Collage'' (1949), abstract expressionist<ref name="AbstractExpressionism"/> * ''La Fiesta'' (1949), abstract expressionist, one of three completed in [[San Miguel de Allende]], Mexico, after marrying Grace Hartigan<ref name="AbstractExpressionism"/> * ''Mexican Composition'' (1949), abstract expressionist, one of three completed in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, after marrying Grace Hartigan<ref name="AbstractExpressionism"/> * ''Random Monoprint'' (1949), abstract expressionist<ref name="AbstractExpressionism"/> * ''Toro Rojo del Sol'' (1949), abstract expressionist, one of three completed in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, after marrying Grace Hartigan<ref name="AbstractExpressionism"/> * ''The Italian Bar'' (1956)<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="Other"/> * ''The Range Burial'' (1963), oil on canvas<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="BBCW"/> * ''The Stampede'' (1965), oil on canvas<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="BBCW"/> * ''Crucifixion at Betio'' (2002), abstract expressionist<ref name="AbstractExpressionism"/> * ''Quartet 1'' (2005), abstract expressionist<ref name="AbstractExpressionism"/> {{div col end}}
===Sculptures=== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} * ''The Range Burial'' (late 1950s), based on his 1963 painting of the same name<ref name="Grimes"/><ref name="Bio"/> * ''Trail Boss'' (1958), bronze, part {{improve categories|date=March 2018}} '''Helen Hall Jennings''' (September 20, 1905 – October 4, 1966) was a social psychologist and a pioneer in the field of [[social network]]s in the early 20th century. She developed quantitative research methods used to study [[sociometry]], a quantitative method for measuring social relationships. This work is cited as being the birth of social network analysis.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/56137876|title=The Development of Social Network Analysis: A Study in the Sociology of Science.|last=Freeman|first=Linton C.|date=2004|publisher=Empirical Press|year=|isbn=1594577145|location=Vancouver, BC|pages=|oclc=56137876}} == Career == Jennings graduated from the [[New Jersey College for Women]] (now known as the [[Douglass Residential College]] at [[Rutgers University]]) in 1927 with a [[Bachelor of Letters]] degree.{{Cite web|url=https://hdl.handle.net/2027/nnc2.ark:/13960/t8sb4s81p?urlappend=;seq=573|title=Catalogue. v. 1930/1931 1897.|website=HathiTrust|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}{{Cite book|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/uc1.b4525470|title=Columbia university alumni register, 1754-1931|last=|first=|date=1932|publisher=New York|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}{{Cite web|url=http://findingaids.cul.columbia.edu/ead/nnc-ua/ldpd_6386066/dsc/1|title=Columbia University Libraries Finding Aids: Columbia University Archives|website=findingaids.cul.columbia.edu|access-date=2018-03-09}} Jennings pursued her graduate degree in [[psychology]] at [[Columbia University]] and specialized in empirical research design. While working in the lab of psychologist [[Gardner Murphy]], she met [[Jacob L. Moreno]]. Through her knowledge of quantitative research methods and [[statistics]], Jennings worked with Moreno to develop an empirical approach to social network research. Together they studied how "social relations affected psychological well-being” and “used quantitative methods for studying the structure of groups and the positions of individuals within groups."{{Cite book|title=Social Network Analysis: History, Theory and Methodology|last= Prell|first= Christina|publisher= SAGE Publications|year= 2011|isbn= 1446290131|pages=22|oclc=761366968}} Jennings and Moreno's research at [[Sing Sing]] and the [[New York Training School for Girls]] (also known as Hudson School for the Girls) "involved systematic data collection and analysis" and resulted in two published works: ''Application of the Group Method to Classification'' in 1932, and ''Who Shall Survive? A New Approach to the Problem of Human Interrelations'' in 1934. This research is responsible for the development of sociometry.{{Cite book|title=The Development of Social Network Analysis: A Study in the Sociology of Science.|last=Freeman|first=Linton C.|publisher=Empirical Press|year=2004|isbn=1594577145|location=Vancouver, BC|pages=35|oclc=56137876}} During this time Jennings and Moreno also become the first to use a stochastic network model (or, "chance sociogram", as they called it) {{cite journal |last1=Moreno |first1=Jacob L |last2=Jennings |first2=Helen Hall |title=Statistics of Social Configurations |journal=Sociometry |date=Jan 1938 |volume=1 |issue=3/4 |pages=342-374 |doi=10.2307/2785588}}, predating the [[Erdős–Rényi model]] and the network model of [[Anatol Rapoport]]{{cite journal |last1=Rapoport |first1=Anatol |title=Contribution to the theory of random and biased nets |journal=The bulletin of mathematical biophysics |date=December 1957 |volume=19 |issue=4 |pages=257–277 |doi=10.1007/BF02478417}}. In 1931, Jennings received her Master of Arts degree from [[Columbia University]]. Her master’s thesis was entitled "The nature of the pathetic."{{Cite web|url=https://clio.columbia.edu/catalog/4312148|title=The nature of the pathetic - CLIO|website=clio.columbia.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}} At that time she was living in Stelton, New Jersey.{{Cite web|url=https://hdl.handle.net/2027/nnc2.ark:/13960/t8sb4s81p?urlappend=;seq=573|title=Catalogue. v. 1930/1931 1897.|website=HathiTrust|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}} In 1943, Jennings completed her PhD thesis ''Leadership and Isolation: A Study of Personality in Interpersonal Relations''.{{Cite web|url=https://clio.columbia.edu/catalog/1937047|title=Leadership and isolation, a study of personality in interpersonal relations - CLIO|website=clio.columbia.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}} It was published by Longman, Greens, and Company.{{Cite book|title=Leadership and Isolation: A Study of Personality in Interpersonal Relations|last= Jennings|first= Helen Hall|publisher= Longman, Greens, and Company.|year= 1943|location= New York|oclc= 751858}} ''Leadership and Isolation'' strove to examine how often-chosen leaders and isolates arise in a population. It was a continuation of analysis from the data collected at the New York Training School for Girls. Research subjects were asked who they would like to work with and who they would like to live with. Eight months later, there was little change in the selected leaders and isolates. [[Benjamin Karpman]], a psychiatrist, reviewed the first edition of ''Leadership and Isolation'' for the ''[[Journal of Clinical Psychology]]''. In his review, he describes the importance of Jennings' research. Karpman closes his review encouraging all psychiatrists to read Jennings’ book, stating "it offers the most profound analysis of leadership and isolation in the social process this reviewer has discovered in the field of social psychology."{{Cite journal|last1=Karpman|first1=Benjamin|date=April 1945|title=Jennings, Helen H. ''Leadership and Isolation: A Study of Personality in Inter-personal Relations''. New York: Longmans, Green. 1943. Pp. vi + 243|journal=Journal of Clinical Psychology|volume=1|issue=2|pages=166–169|doi=10.1002/1097-4679(194504)1:2<166::AID-JCLP2270010218>3.0.CO;2-J}} A second edition of ''Leadership and Isolation'' was published by Longman, Greens, and Company in 1950.{{Cite book|title=Leadership and Isolation: A Study of Personality in Interpersonal Relations|last= Jennings|first= Helen Hall|publisher= Longman, Greens, and Company.|year= 1950|location= New York|oclc= 217786}} [[Morris Janowitz]], a founder of [[military sociology]], reviewed the book for the ''[[American Journal of Sociology]]''. In his review, Janowitz wrote that ''Leadership and Isolation'' "can be viewed as an ingenious empirical study which helped fashion sociometry as a research tool."{{Cite journal |last1= Janowitz|first1= Morris|date= July 1951|title= ''Leadership and Isolation: A Study of Personality in Interpersonal Relations''. Helen Hall Jennings|journal= American Journal of Sociology|volume= 51|issue= 1|pages= 84–85|doi= 10.1086/220864}} According to structural [[sociology|sociologist]] [[Linton Freeman|Linton C. Freeman]], the empirical methods developed by Jennings and applied in Moreno’s sociometry studies laid the groundwork for future social network research:
"Clearly, with a great deal of help from Jennings and Lazarsfeld, Moreno had developed an approach that included all of the defining properties of social network analysis. It was based on structural intuitions, it involved the collection of systematic empirical data, graphic imagery was an integral part of its tools and it embodied an explicit mathematical model. That structural perspective, moreover, was generalized to a range of phenomena. Thus, the group led by Moreno displayed all four of the features that define social network analysis."{{Cite book|title=The Development of Social Network Analysis: A Study in the Sociology of Science|last=Freeman|first=Linton C.|publisher=Empirical Press|year=2004|isbn=1594577145|location=Vancouver, BC|pages=39|oclc=56137876}}
Freeman draws the conclusion that Jennings was instrumental in the empirical research done in support of theories from Moreno:
"My own suspicion is that Jennings's contributions were immense. Moreno had no research training at all, and until this point, he had shown absolutely no interest in systematic research. All of his earlier publications were couched in heavy mysticism. But his newer works–those produced during his collaboration with Jennings–were comparatively systematic and were, for the first time, empirically grounded. The obvious conclusion is that, though the intuitive ideas came from Moreno, the completed research and the publications drew heavily on the contributions of Jennings. Jennings, it seems, was not only a collaborator but she was, in Moreno's terms, a very powerful 'muse.'"{{Cite book|title=The Development of Social Network Analysis: A Study in the Sociology of Science|last=Freeman|first=Linton C.|publisher=Empirical Press|year=2004|isbn=1594577145|location=Vancouver, BC|pages=36|oclc=56137876}}
== Selected works == * Moreno, Jacob L. and Jennings, Helen Hall. (1938). ''Statistics of social configurations.'' Sociometry, Vol. 1, pp. 342-374. * Jennings, Helen Hall. (1947). ''Sociometry of Leadership: Based on the Differentiation of Psychegroup and Sociogroup.'' Beacon House. {{oclc|3954870}} * Jennings, Helen Hall. (1950). ''Leadership and Isolation: A Study of Personality in Interpersonal Relations''. New York: Longman, Greens, and Company. {{oclc|217786}} * Jennings, Helen Hall. (1959). ''Sociometry in Group Relations: A Manual for Teachers.'' American Council on Education. {{oclc|255156}} {{asin|B000WL0G9C}} == References == {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jennings, Helen Hall}} [[Category:Douglass College alumni]] [[Category:American women psychologists]] [[Category:Date of death unknown]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:1905 births]] [[Category:Researchers]] [[Category:Social networks]]

{{Infobox person |name = James Oberg |image = ObergTrainer.jpg |caption = Oberg at the Johnson Space Center in 1978 |alt = James E. Oberg visits the Space Shuttle orbiter trainer at the Johnson Space Center, Dallas, Texas, 1978 |birth_name = James Edward Oberg |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1944|11|7}} |birth_place = [[New York City]], United States |education = [[Ohio Wesleyan University]], [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] [[Mathematics]], 1966;
[[Northwestern University]], [[Master of Science|M.S.]] [[Applied Mathematics]] ([[Orbital mechanics|Astrodynamics]]), 1969;
[[University of New Mexico]], M.S. [[Computer Science]], 1972 |other_names = Jim Oberg |residence = [[Dickinson, Texas]], United States |nationality = American |occupation = [[Journalist]], [[historian]], [[author]] |website = {{URL|http://www.jamesoberg.com/}} |spouse = Alcestis (married 1969–present) |children = 2 |awards = See [[#Awards]] }} '''James Edward Oberg''' (born November 7, 1944), often known as '''Jim Oberg''', is an American space [[journalist]] and [[historian]], regarded as an expert on the [[Russian space program|Russian]] and [[Chinese space program]]s.{{cite web|url = http://www.debunker.com/texts/soviet.html|title = Soviet Saucers|last = Oberg|first = James|date = April 1994|work = [[Omni (magazine)|Omni]]|publisher = General Media, Inc.|accessdate = June 23, 2009|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090207104956/http://debunker.com/texts/soviet.html|archivedate = February 7, 2009|df = }}{{cite web|url = http://w2.eff.org/Misc/Publications/Bruce_Sterling/Catscan_columns/catscan.14|title = Catscan 14: 'Memories of the Space Age'|last = Sterling|first = Bruce|authorlink = Bruce Sterling|work = [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]]|quote = Oberg is a recognized Soviet Space expert, sometime NOVA host on PBS, special consultant to the Sotheby's auction house for Soviet space memorabilia, and the author of the definitive tome RED STAR IN ORBIT (Random House 1981).|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091004115836/http://w2.eff.org/Misc/Publications/Bruce_Sterling/Catscan_columns/catscan.14|archivedate = 2009-10-04|df = }} Catscan archive homepage [http://w2.eff.org/Misc/Publications/Bruce_Sterling/Catscan_columns/ here.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091004095737/http://w2.eff.org/Misc/Publications/Bruce_Sterling/Catscan_columns/ |date=2009-10-04 }} He had a 22-year career as a space engineer in [[NASA]] specializing in [[Space rendezvous|orbital rendezvous]]. Oberg is an author of ten books and more than a thousand articles on space flight. He gave many explanations of [[Unidentified flying object|UFO]] phenomena in the popular press. He is also a consultant in spaceflight operations and safety. == Early life and education == James Oberg was born in [[New York City]] on November 7, 1944.{{cite web|last1 = Oberg|first1 = James|title = U.S./Russian Aerospace Consultancies|url = http://www.jamesoberg.com/resumeconsultancies.html|website = JamesOberg.com|accessdate = 2016-08-01|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160331100926/http://jamesoberg.com/resumeconsultancies.html|archivedate = 2016-03-31}} He received a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in [[Mathematics]] from [[Ohio Wesleyan University]] in 1966, a [[Master of Science|M.S.]] in [[Applied Mathematics]] ([[Orbital mechanics|Astrodynamics]]) from [[Northwestern University]] in 1969 (where he was also a NASA Trainee) and a M.S. in [[Computer Science]] from [[University of New Mexico]] in 1972. == US Air Force == At Northwestern University he started [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] work in Mathematics, but was called to active duty by the [[United States Air Force]] in 1970. There he worked with modeling [[laser]] and [[nuclear weapon]]s and in the years 1972–1975, while working in the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] Computer Institute, he helped design and test [[ARPANET]], ancestor of the Internet. == NASA == After service in the [[United States Air Force]], he joined [[NASA]] in 1975, where he worked until 1997 at [[Johnson Space Center]] on the [[Space Shuttle program]]. He worked in the [[Mission Control Center]] for several [[Space Shuttle]] missions from [[STS-1]] on, specializing in [[Space rendezvous|orbital rendezvous]] techniques. This culminated in planning the orbit for the [[STS-88]] mission, the first [[International Space Station]] (ISS) assembly flight. During the 1990s, he was involved in NASA studies of the [[Soviet space program]], with particular emphasis on safety aspects;{{cite web|last1 = Oberg|first1 = James|title = Aerospace Career Specialities|url = http://www.jamesoberg.com/resumeaerospace.html|website = JamesOberg.com|accessdate = 2016-08-02|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160331035215/http://jamesoberg.com/resumeaerospace.html|archivedate = 2016-03-31}} these had often been covered up or downplayed, and with the advent of the ISS and the [[Shuttle–Mir Program|Shuttle–''Mir'']] programs, NASA was keen to study them as much as possible. He privately published several books on the Soviet (and later Russian) programs, and became one of the few Western specialists on Russian space history. He has often been called to testify before the [[United States Congress|US Congress]] on the Russian space program.{{cite web|url = http://www.houstonspacesociety.org/ist/oberg.html|title = Testimony of James Oberg|date = October 7, 1998|work = In Space Today|publisher = Houston Space Society|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/19990505182605/http://houstonspacesociety.org/ist/oberg.html|archivedate = May 5, 1999|accessdate = May 10, 2013}} In 1997 he voluntarily resigned from NASA and started a full-time free-lance career.{{cite web|last1 = Oberg|first1 = James|title = FAQ|url = http://www.jamesoberg.com/faq.html|website = JamesOberg.com|accessdate = 2016-08-02|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160505164235/http://www.jamesoberg.com/faq.html|archivedate = 2016-05-05}} Currently he works as a consultant in spaceflight operations and safety and as a space journalist. == Author and journalist == As a journalist, Oberg writes for several publications, mostly online; he was previously a space correspondent or commentator for [[United Press International|UPI]], [[ABC News]] and currently [[MSNBC]],{{cite web|last1 = Oberg|first1 = James|title = Profile|url = http://www.jamesoberg.com/profile.html|website = JamesOberg.com|accessdate = 2016-08-02|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160505164742/http://www.jamesoberg.com/profile.html|archivedate = 2016-05-05}} often in an on-air role. He is a Fellow of the skeptical organization [[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry|CSICOP]] and a consultant to its magazine ''[[Skeptical Inquirer]]''. He authored more than a thousand magazine and newspaper articles, including such magazines as ''[[The Wall Street Journal]], [[USA Today]], [[Scientific American]], [[Omni (magazine)|OMNI]], [[Popular Science]], [[Popular Mechanics]], [[New Scientist]], [[IEEE Spectrum]], Air Force Magazine, Star and Sky'', etc. Oberg is also a space consultant and on-air commentator to [[NBC News]], [[Discovery Channel (Canada)|Discovery Canada]] and the [[BBC]]. In December 1990, ''[[Horizon (BBC TV series)|Horizon]]'', a British television science and philosophy television documentary program, aired a three-part series, "Red Star in Orbit," based on Oberg's book of the same name. [[WGBH-TV|WGBH Boston]] adapted the ''Horizon'' series for its ''[[Nova (TV series)|Nova]]'' television science series, a three-part [[miniseries]] titled "The Russian Right Stuff," which aired in February 1991.{{cite web|url = https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/listseason/18.html|title = NOVA : Past Television Programs : Season 18: January–December 1991 : PBS|work = PBS Online|publisher = [[WGBH-TV|WGBH]]|location = Boston, MA|accessdate = May 12, 2013|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131001184522/http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/listseason/18.html|archivedate = October 1, 2013|df = }} [[HBO]] has optioned ''Red Star in Orbit'' for a future production. Also in 1991, Oberg launched a battle for official recognition of [[Robert Henry Lawrence, Jr.]] (1935–1967) as a United States [[astronaut]]; the [[United States Air Force]] officially recognized Lawrence in January 1997, six years after Oberg had begun his campaign.{{cite book|last1 = Gubert|first1 = Betty Kaplan|last2 = Sawyer|first2 = Miriam|last3 = Fannin|first3 = Caroline M.|title = Distinguished African Americans in Aviation and Space Science|date = 2001|publisher = [[Greenwood Publishing Group|Oryx Press]]|location = Westport, CT|isbn = 978-1-57356-246-1}} In 1999, Oberg authored ''Space Power Theory'', sponsored by [[United States Armed Forces|United States military]]{{cite book|last = Handberg|first = Roger|title = Seeking New World Vistas: The Militarization of Space|date = 2000|publisher = [[Greenwood Publishing Group|Praeger Publishers]]|location = Westport, CT|isbn = 978-0-275-96295-1}} as a part of an official campaign in changing perceptions of [[space warfare]], specifically deployment and use of weapons in outer space, and its political implications. "In Oberg's view, space is not an extension of air warfare but is unique in itself." James Oberg is an author of ten books in addition to several technical NASA publications.{{cite web|last1 = Oberg|first1 = James|title = Books – NASA|url = http://www.jamesoberg.com/nasa.html|website = JamesOberg.com|accessdate = 2016-08-03|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160328135037/http://jamesoberg.com/nasa.html|archivedate = 2016-03-28}} He also wrote encyclopedia articles on space exploration in the ''[[World Book Encyclopedia]], [[Encyclopædia Britannica|Britannica]]'' yearbook, ''[[Grolier]]'' and ''[[Academic American Encyclopedia]]''. == Moon landing conspiracies == [[File:Apollo 11 Crew During Training Exercise - GPN-2002-000032.jpg|thumb|One of the photos taken during a simulation used by conspiracy theorists]] Oberg was commissioned by NASA to write a [[rebuttal]] of [[Apollo program|Apollo]] [[Moon landing conspiracy theories]]. However, NASA dropped the project after [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s World News Tonight program ran a story about it, claiming it was beneath NASA's dignity to respond to Moon landing [[Denialism|denialists]] claims. Oberg has said that he still intends to pursue the project, "depending on successfully arranging new funding sources."{{cite journal|last=Oberg|first=James|date=March–April 2003|title=Lessons of the 'Fake Moon Flight' Myth|journal=[[Skeptical Inquirer]]|location=Amherst, NY|publisher=[[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]]|pages=23, 30|accessdate=April 27, 2013|url=http://www.jamesoberg.com/042003lessonsfake_his.html|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130624135823/http://www.jamesoberg.com/042003lessonsfake_his.html|archivedate=June 24, 2013|df=}} Reprinted in [[Kendrick Frazier|Frazier, Kendrick]] (ed.) (2009). ''Science Under Siege: Defending Science, Exposing Pseudoscience''. Amherst, NY: [[Prometheus Books]]. {{ISBN|978-1-59102-715-7}}.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/2424927.stm|accessdate=August 26, 2009|title=Nasa pulls Moon hoax book|date=November 8, 2002|first=David|last=Whitehouse|work=BBC News|location=London|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090203053109/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/2424927.stm|archivedate=February 3, 2009|df=}} Oberg writes that Moon landing conspiracy theories are fueled by resentment of American culture by some countries. He gives the example of [[Cuba]], where many school teachers claim the landing was a fraud.{{cite news|title=Getting Apollo 11 Right|first=James|last=Oberg|authorlink=James Oberg|url=http://abcnews.go.com/ABC2000/abc2000science/oberg2000.html|accessdate=August 13, 2009|work=ABC News|publisher=ABC|location=New York|date=July 1999|quote=I'm told that this is official dogma still taught in schools in Cuba, plus wherever else Cuban teachers have been sent (such as [[Sandinista]] Nicaragua and Angola).|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030402094521/http://abcnews.go.com/ABC2000/abc2000science/oberg2000.html|archivedate=April 2, 2003}} But besides this, the new wave of conspiracy theorists appear to use alternative publication methods to publicize their claims. Oberg says that belief in the conspiracy is not the fault of the hoaxists, but rather of educators and people (including NASA) who should provide information to the public. NASA does not, in Oberg's opinion, provide an adequate reaction to the theorists' claims. == North Korean satellite launch inspection == [[File:North Korean Unha-3 rocket at launch pad.jpg|thumb|North Korean Unha-3 space rocket]] In April 2012 Oberg traveled to [[North Korea]] as a NBC space consultant{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/47204491/ns/technology_and_science-space/t/what-we-learned-north-koreas-rocket-no-show/|title=What we learned from North Korea's rocket no-show|last=Oberg|first=James|date=2012-04-27|website=[[NBC News]]|accessdate=2016-08-25|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160928001442/http://www.nbcnews.com/id/47204491/ns/technology_and_science-space/t/what-we-learned-north-koreas-rocket-no-show/|archivedate=2016-09-28|df=}} to observe the launching of the [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3]] satellite and determine whether it is a military launch. Together with a team of journalists[[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3#Media coverage]] he inspected the [[Sohae Satellite Launching Station]], the [[Unha]] rocket and the satellite. According to Oberg, North Korea "showed everything but the important things"{{cite web|url=http://www.thespacereview.com/article/2262/1|title=Using "rocket science" to understand North Korea's space and missile efforts|last=Oberg|first=James|date=2012-12-03|newspaper=[[The Space Review]]|accessdate=2016-08-26|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160914185744/http://www.thespacereview.com/article/2262/1|archivedate=2016-09-14|df=}} and did not manage to demonstrate peaceful intent. == UFO investigation == James Oberg often writes about alleged [[Unidentified flying object|UFO]] sightings, giving scientific explanations to seemingly [[Extraterrestrial life|extraterrestrial]] phenomena, or otherwise debunking them as hoaxes. Oberg categorized UFO sightings (excluding those identified as hoaxes) into one of three groups:{{cite web|last1 = Giaimo|first1 = Cara|title = How One Man Has Explained Almost Every Internet UFO Theory|url = http://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/how-one-man-has-explained-almost-every-internet-ufo-theory|website = Atlas Obscura|accessdate = 2016-08-04|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160804110917/http://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/how-one-man-has-explained-almost-every-internet-ufo-theory|archivedate = 2016-08-04}}{{cite web|last1 = Pavlou|first1 = George|title = Former NASA Employee Explains Almost Every UFO Sighting|url = http://www.theladbible.com/more/interesting-former-nasa-employee-explains-almost-every-ufo-sighting-20160608|website = The LAD bible|accessdate = 2016-08-04|date = 2016-06-08}}{{cite web|title = Former Nasa employee explains what's REALLY behind conspiracy theories|website = Mail Online|date = 2016-06-07|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3628974/UFO-sightings-debunked-Former-Nasa-employee-explains-s-REALLY-popular-alien-conspiracies-theories.html|accessdate = 2016-08-04|archiveurl = https://archive.is/20160615023048/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3628974/UFO-sightings-debunked-Former-Nasa-employee-explains-s-REALLY-popular-alien-conspiracies-theories.html|archivedate = 2016-06-15}}{{cite web|last1 = Didymus|first1 = Johnthomas|title = UFOs debunked? Former NASA employee James Oberg explains away ufo sighting claims|url = http://www.inquisitr.com/3181942/ufos-debunked-former-nasa-employee-james-oberg-explains-away-ufo-sighting-claims-video/|website = INQUISITR|accessdate = 2016-08-08|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160807190744/http://www.inquisitr.com/3181942/ufos-debunked-former-nasa-employee-james-oberg-explains-away-ufo-sighting-claims-video/|archivedate = 2016-08-07|df = }} # ''Super-High Plumes'' – rocket or missile plumes, especially lit by the sun on a dark sky; # ''Space "Dandruff"'' – ice flakes, fragments of insulation, etc. flying alongside a space vehicle, especially seen by backward-facing cameras; # ''Twilight Shadowing'' – objects that move from shadow into sunlight in space appear as if coming from behind the clouds or from beyond the edge of the Earth. === List of UFO explanations === {|class="wikitable" |- !
