What IS it? What ISN'T it? WHY the confusion?|url=http://www.jamesoberg.com/sts88_and-black-knight.pdf|website=JamesOberg.com|accessdate=2016-08-23|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170120122042/http://www.jamesoberg.com/sts88_and-black-knight.pdf|archivedate=2017-01-20|df=}}{{Skeptoid|id=4365|number=365|title=The Black Knight Satellite|accessdate=2016-08-23|date=2013-06-04}} |} == Russian pistol aboard ISS == [[File:TP-82.jpg|thumb|Triple-barreled [[TP-82 Cosmonaut survival pistol]] pistol in Saint-Petersburg Artillery museum]] James Oberg wrote several articles as a publicity campaign to remove guns from the ISS.{{cite web|last1 = Oberg|first1 = James|title = Russia has the corner on guns in space|url = http://www.nbcnews.com/id/23131359/ns/technology_and_science-space/t/russia-has-corner-guns-space/|website = NBC news|accessdate = 2016-08-08|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160316151418/http://www.nbcnews.com/id/23131359/ns/technology_and_science-space/t/russia-has-corner-guns-space/|archivedate = 2016-03-16}}{{cite web|last1 = Oberg|first1 = James|title = The Russian Gun at the International Space Station|url = http://www.jamesoberg.com/russiangun_tec.html|website = JamesOberg.com|accessdate = 2016-08-08|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160310105739/http://www.jamesoberg.com/russiangun_tec.html|archivedate = 2016-03-10}} The [[TP-82 Cosmonaut survival pistol]] was stowed in the [[Soyuz programme|Soyuz]] emergency landing survival kit and was added there for hunting and self-defense after landing in inhospitable environment. It had three barrels and a folding stock that doubled as a [[shovel]] and contained a [[machete]]. The gun was only carried by Russian members of the ISS. Oberg suggested that it might be an invitation to a future disaster and proposed it to be put in a compartment accessible only from outside, after landing. In 2014 Oberg asked [[Samantha Cristoforetti]], an Italian ISS astronaut, about the pistol and she admitted the gun is removed from the list, or more precisely, it is still on the official list of kit contents, but the committee meets before every mission to review the list and vote to remove the pistol for the specific flight.{{cite web|last1 = Oberg|first1 = James|title = How I Stopped Cosmonauts From Carrying Guns|url = http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/aerospace/space-flight/how-i-stop-cosmonauts-carrying-guns|website = IEEE SPECTRUM|accessdate = 2016-08-08|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160415193637/http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/aerospace/space-flight/how-i-stop-cosmonauts-carrying-guns|archivedate = 2016-04-15}} == Private life == Oberg has been married since 1969 and lives with his wife Alcestis in [[Dickinson, Texas]]. He has two grown sons (born 1977 and 1984).{{cite web|last1 = Oberg|first1 = James|title = Journalism|url = http://www.jamesoberg.com/resumejournalism.html|website = JamesOberg.com|accessdate = 2016-08-02|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160331053349/http://jamesoberg.com/resumejournalism.html|archivedate = 2016-03-31}} He speaks [[English language|English]], [[Russian language|Russian]], [[French language|French]] and [[Latin language|Latin]], and has some familiarity with [[German language|German]], [[Swedish language|Swedish]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Kazakh language|Kazakh]] and [[Japanese language|Japanese]]. {{anchor|Awards}}{{anchor|Memberships}} ==Awards and memberships== * First place in Goddard National Space Award (twice) * 1st and 2nd place awards from the [[American Society of Business Publication Editors]] (May 2000) * The winner of the [[New Scientist]] award: Cutty Sark Whisky essay on UFO{{cite journal|last1=Oberg|first1=James|title=The failure of the 'science' of UFOlogy|journal=[[New Scientist]]|date=1979-10-11|url=http://www.debunker.com/texts/ObergCuttySark.html|accessdate=2016-08-24|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819112825/http://www.debunker.com/texts/ObergCuttySark.html|archivedate=2016-08-19}} {{indent}} * Fellow of the skeptical organization [[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry|CSICOP]]; * Fellow of the [[British Interplanetary Society]]; * Fellow of the Russian Academy of Cosmonautics (the first foreign member); * Fellow of the [[American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics]] == Bibliography == === Popular publications === {{refbegin|30em}} # {{cite book|last1 = Oberg|first1 = James|last2 = Edmondson|first2 = Harold|title = Famous Spaceships of Fact and Fantasy|date = 1979|publisher = Kalmbach Publishing Company|isbn = 9780890245392}} # {{Cite book|last = Oberg|first = James|others = Foreword by [[Jack Williamson]]|title = New Earths: Restructuring Earth and Other Planets|publisher = Stackpole Books|date = 1981|location = Harrisburg, PA|isbn = 978-0-452-00623-2}} # {{Cite book|last = Oberg|first = James|others = Foreword by [[Tom Wolfe]]|title = Red Star in Orbit|publisher = Random House|date = 1981|location = New York|isbn = 978-0-394-51429-1}} # {{Cite book|last = Oberg|first = James|others = Foreword by [[G. Harry Stine]]|title = Mission to Mars: Plans and Concepts for the First Manned Landing|publisher = Stackpole Books|date = 1982|location = Harrisburg, PA|isbn = 978-0-81170-432-8}} # {{Cite book|last = Oberg|first = James|title = UFO's and Outer Space Mysteries: A Sympathetic Skeptic's Report|publisher = Donning Company Publishers|date = 1982|location = Norfolk, VA|isbn = 978-0-89865-102-7}} # {{Cite book|last = Oberg|first = James|others = Foreword by [[Ben Bova]]|title = The New Race for Space: The U.S. and Russia Leap to the Challenge for Unlimited Rewards|publisher = Stackpole Books|date = 1984|location = Harrisburg, PA|isbn = 978-0-8117-2177-6}} # {{Cite book|last1 = Oberg|first1 = James|last2 = Oberg|first2 = Alcestis R.|others = Foreword by [[Isaac Asimov]]|title = Pioneering Space: Living on the Next Frontier|publisher = McGraw-Hill|date = 1986|location = New York|isbn = 978-0-07-048039-1}} # {{Cite book|last = Oberg|first = James|title = Uncovering Soviet Disasters: Exploring the Limits of Glasnost|publisher = Random House|date = 1988|location = New York|isbn = 978-0-394-56095-3}} # {{Cite book|last1 = Oberg|first1 = James|last2 = Sullivan|first2 = Brian R.|others = Introductions by Colin S. Gray and Howell M. Estes III|title = Space Power Theory|publisher = US Air Force Academy|date = 1999|location = Colorado Springs, CO|oclc = 41145918}} # {{Cite book|last = Oberg|first = James|title = Star-Crossed Orbits: Inside the U.S.-Russian Space Alliance|publisher = McGraw-Hill|date = 2001|location = New York|isbn = 978-0-07137-425-5}} {{refend}} === Upcoming books {{cite web|last1 = Oberg|first1 = James|title = Books|url = http://www.jamesoberg.com/books.html|website = JamesOberg.com|accessdate = 2016-08-02|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160505161955/http://www.jamesoberg.com/books.html|archivedate = 2016-05-05}}=== {{refbegin}} * The Mars Conquest * Red Stars in Orbit {{refend}} === Technical materials for NASA=== {{refbegin}} * Space Shuttle Mission Control Center: Overview of Information and Decision Flows (for McDonnell Douglas); * Rendezvous and Proximity Operations Handbook; * History of Orbital Rendezvous; * Flight Data File: Crew Procedures, STS-32 LDEF Retrieval; * Console Handbook, Rendezvous Guidance and Procedures Officer; * Training Guide, Rendezvous Guidance and Procedures Handbook {{refend}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.jamesoberg.com/profile.html Profile at jamesoberg.com] {{Authority control}} {{Use American English|date = January 2014}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Oberg, James}} [[Category:American male journalists]] [[Category:Journalists from New York City]] [[Category:United States Air Force airmen]] [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Military personnel from New York City]] [[Category:Northwestern University alumni]] [[Category:Ohio Wesleyan University alumni]] [[Category:University of New Mexico alumni]] [[Category:American skeptics]] [[Category:NASA people]] [[Category:Fellows of the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]] [[Category:UFO skeptics]] [[Category:Writers from New York City]] [[Category:People from Dickinson, Texas]]

{{lead too long|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox person | image = Judy Greer July 14, 2014 (cropped).jpg | caption = Greer in 2014 | birth_name = Judith Therese Evans | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1975|7|20}} | birth_place = [[Detroit|Detroit, Michigan]], U.S. | years_active = 1997–present | alma_mater = [[DePaul University]] | residence = [[Los Angeles]], California, U.S.<ref name=wsj/> | occupation = {{flatlist| * Actress * model * author }} | spouse = {{marriage|Dean E. Johnsen|2011}} }} '''Judith Therese Evans''' (born July 20, 1975), known professionally as '''Judy Greer''', is an American actress, director, model, and author. She is primarily known as a [[character actor]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Bramesco|first=Charles|work=[[Nylon (magazine)|Nylon]]|url=https://nylon.com/articles/judy-greer-joy-frustration-character-actress|title=Fact: Judy Greer Is The Best Person In Hollywood|date=March 28, 2017|accessdate=September 19, 2018}}</ref> who has appeared in a variety of comedic and dramatic films.
A native of [[Detroit]], Greer studied theater at [[DePaul University]] in [[Chicago]] before appearing in several independent films. She had her first major role in the black comedy ''[[Jawbreaker (film)|Jawbreaker]]'' (1999), followed by a supporting role as a journalist in [[David O. Russell]]'s war film ''[[Three Kings (1999 film)|Three Kings]]'' (1999). Greer went on to have supporting roles in several romantic comedies, such as ''[[What Women Want]]'' (2000), ''[[The Wedding Planner]]'' (2001), ''[[13 Going on 30]]'' (2004), ''[[Elizabethtown (film)|Elizabethtown]]'' (2005), ''[[27 Dresses]]'' (2008), and ''[[Love & Other Drugs]]'' (2010). Greer also had various supporting roles in dramatic films, including the meta comedy-drama ''[[Adaptation (film)|Adaptation]]'' (2002) and the psychological thriller ''[[The Village (2004 film)|The Village]]'' (2004).
On television, Greer was cast in recurring guest roles on the television comedy series ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]'' as [[List of recurring Arrested Development characters#Kitty Sanchez|Kitty Sanchez]], and as Fatty Magoo in ''[[It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia]]''. Between 2007 and 2012, she had a recurring role on the [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] series [[Californication (TV series)|''Californication'']], and has provided the voice of [[Cheryl Tunt]] in the animated comedy series ''[[Archer (2009 TV series)|Archer]]'' since 2009. She stars in the Showtime comedy-drama series ''[[Kidding]]''.
In the early 2010s, Greer had supporting roles in the drama film ''[[The Descendants]]'' (2011), as well as the 2013 horror remake ''[[Carrie (2013 film)|Carrie]]''. In 2014, Greer began appearing in several action and science fiction films, portraying Cornelia in ''[[Dawn of the Planet of the Apes]]'', a role she later reprised in the sequel film ''[[War for the Planet of the Apes]]'' (2017). In the [[Marvel Cinematic Universe]], she portrays Maggie Lang, appearing in ''[[Ant-Man (film)|Ant-Man]]'' (2015) and ''[[Ant-Man and the Wasp]]'' (2018). She also had supporting roles in ''[[Jurassic World]]'' (2015) and [[David Gordon Green]]'s horror film ''[[Halloween (2018 film)|Halloween]]'' (2018). She made her directorial debut in 2017 with the comedy-drama film ''[[A Happening of Monumental Proportions]]''.
In 2011, Greer began hosting an online series of workout videos called ''Reluctantly Healthy'', which was adapted into a series by [[Litton Entertainment]] in 2014 as part of their Saturday morning ''[[One Magnificent Morning]]'' block for [[The CW]].<ref name=Rel>{{cite web|url=http://screen.yahoo.com/women/reluctantly-healthy/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130209190319/http://screen.yahoo.com/women/reluctantly-healthy/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-09 |title=Reluctantly Healthy Video |publisher=[[Yahoo!]] |accessdate=June 16, 2017 |df= }}</ref> Also in 2014, she released her first autobiographical novel, titled ''I Don't Know What You Know Me From: Confessions of a Co-Star''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Luberecki|first1=Beth |title=Judy Greer dishes on her new book 'I Don't Know What You Know Me From' |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/express/wp/2014/05/14/judy-greer-dishes-on-her-new-book-i-dont-know-what-you-know-me-from/|accessdate=July 14, 2014|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=May 14, 2014}}</ref>
==Early life== Greer was born Judith Therese Evans on July 20, 1975<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/entertainment/judy-greer-laments-rom-com-decline-while-promoting-new-book-1.1768644 |title=Judy Greer laments rom-com decline while promoting new book |publisher=CTV News |date=April 9, 2014 |accessdate=April 21, 2014 |first=Victoria |last=Ahearn }}</ref><ref name=allmovie>{{cite web| url = https://www.nytimes.com/movies/person/235491/Judy-Greer/biography | title= Judy Greer; Alternate Name: Judy Evans Greer, Judith Laura Evans, Judy Evans, Judith Laura Evans| publisher= [[AllMovie]] / [[Rovi]] via ''[[The New York Times]]'' | first=Andrea | last=LeVasseur|accessdate= September 26, 2014}}</ref> in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]. Her mother, Mollie Ann (''[[née]]'' Greer), is a hospital administrator, and her father, Rich Evans, is a mechanical engineer.{{sfn|Greer|2014|p=25}}<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/dec/27/judy-greer-arrested-development-get-flashed |title=Judy Greer: 'I get flashed all the time. It's mostly men' |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=December 27, 2012 |first=Hermione |last=Hoby }}</ref> Her mother was once a nun who had left the convent after eight years, being "kicked out" for wild behavior, including owning a red bathing suit.<ref name="colbert2017">{{cite news|title=Judy Greer Starred Alongside Stephen In A Rejected 2002 Pilot|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NZ05TIoEYUM |accessdate=June 16, 2017|work=[[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert]]|date=June 16, 2017}}</ref> Greer was raised [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]],<ref name=wsj>{{cite web|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/behind-the-scenes-with-judy-greer-1400285798 |title=Behind the Scenes with Judy Greer|author=Wolfe, Alexandra|date=May 16, 2014 |accessdate=September 19, 2018}} {{closed access}}</ref> and grew up in [[Redford Charter Township, Michigan|Redford Township]] and [[Livonia, Michigan|Livonia]].<ref name=krug/> She attended [[Winston Churchill High School (Wayne County, Michigan)|Churchill High School]]<ref name=krug>{{cite web|work=[[Metro Times|The Metro Times]]|location=Detroit|url=https://www.metrotimes.com/news-hits/archives/2014/10/23/livonia-native-judy-greer-on-films-tv-and-her-new-book|title=Livonia native Judy Greer on films, TV, and her new book|author=Krug, Kurt Anthony|date=October 23, 2014|accessdate=September 17, 2018|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180919171727/https://www.metrotimes.com/news-hits/archives/2014/10/23/livonia-native-judy-greer-on-films-tv-and-her-new-book#|archivedate=2018-09-19|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> and graduated from The Theatre School at [[DePaul University]] in 1997 with a [[Bachelor of Fine Arts]] degree.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://theatreschool.depaul.edu/special_programs_awards.php | title = Awards For Excellence In The Arts | accessdate = July 30, 2010 | publisher = The Theater School at DePaul University |archivedate= August 13, 2006 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060813042958/http://theatreschool.depaul.edu/special_programs_awards.php}}</ref> She later adopted her mother's maiden name for her stage name, as there were several other actresses named Judy or Judi Evans.
==Career== Greer made her film debut in the horror film ''Stricken'' (1998), in which she played a college student involved in a fatal prank.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/stricken/|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|title=Stricken (1998)|accessdate=September 17, 2018}}</ref> This was followed by a small role in the Chicago-filmed drama ''[[Kissing a Fool]]'' (1998). She was then cast in her first major role as Fern Mayo, a nerdy teenager who uncovers her classmates' murder of their friend, in [[Darren Stein]]'s black comedy ''[[Jawbreaker (film)|Jawbreaker]]'' (1999).<ref name=jb>{{cite web|work=[[Vice Media|Broadly]]|url=https://broadly.vice.com/en_us/article/paeyk9/perverting-the-youth-of-america-the-oral-history-of-teen-classic-jawbreaker|title='Perverting the Youth of America': The Oral History of Teen Classic 'Jawbreaker'|date=August 14, 2016 |accessdate=September 19, 2018|author=Sunderland, Mitchell}}</ref> The film would go on to earn a [[cult following]].<ref name=jb/> Greer followed this with small parts in the romantic comedy films ''[[What Women Want]]'' (2000)<ref>{{cite web|work=[[BBC One]]|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0074dkr|title=What Women Want|accessdate=September 17, 2018|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180919175803/https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0074dkr#|archivedate=2018-09-19|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> and ''[[The Wedding Planner]]'' (2001), opposite [[Jennifer Lopez]].<ref name=talks>{{cite web|url=https://ew.com/article/2015/10/01/judy-greer-married-memorable-roles/|date=October 1, 2015|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|title=Judy Greer talks 'Arrested Development,' '13 Going on 30,' 'The Descendants,' 'The Wedding Planner,' and more...|author=Li, Shirley|accessdate=September 19, 2018}}</ref> She was cast in a 2002 pilot for NBC alongside [[Stephen Colbert]], ''Untitled Ken Finkleman Project'' ([[Imagine Entertainment]]), based on the Canadian show ''[[The Newsroom (Canadian TV series)|The Newsroom]]'' from [[Ken Finkleman]]. Colbert portrayed Finkleman and Greer played his sister.<ref name="colbert2017"/>
Greer had recurring role on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] comedy series ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]'' (2003–2005, 2013, 2018), playing [[List of recurring Arrested Development characters|Kitty Sanchez]] in 10 episodes total and appearing in each of the series' three original seasons. In a 2009 interview, Greer said that she is most recognized for this role.<ref name="goldman">{{cite web | url = http://tv.ign.com/articles/101/1014154p1.html | title = Judy Greer Gets Animated with Glenn Martin, DDS and Archer |accessdate=July 30, 2010 |last=Goldman |first=Eric |date= August 14, 2009 |publisher= IGN}}</ref> Greer also had supporting roles in ''[[Jawbreaker (film)|Jawbreaker]]'' (1999), ''[[What Women Want]]'' (2000), ''[[The Wedding Planner]]'' (2001), ''[[Adaptation (film)|Adaptation]]'' (2002), ''[[13 Going on 30]]'' (2004), ''[[The Village (2004 film)|The Village]]'' (2004), ''[[Elizabethtown (film)|Elizabethtown]]'' (2005), ''[[27 Dresses]]'' (2008), and ''[[Love Happens]]'' (2009).
Greer made guest appearances on ''[[Just Shoot Me!]]'' (2003), ''[[CSI: Miami]]'' (2005), ''[[My Name Is Earl]]'' (2006), ''[[It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia]]'' (2007, 2011), ''[[Californication (TV series)|Californication]]'' (2007–2008, 2012), ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'' (2009), ''[[House (TV series)|House]]'' (2009), ''[[Modern Family]]'' (2010), ''[[The Big Bang Theory]]'' (2010), ''[[How I Met Your Mother]]'' (2010) and ''[[Warren the Ape]]'' (2010). She took on a starring role in the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] sitcom ''[[Miss Guided]]'' (2008), but it was canceled in its first season.<ref>Seidman, Robert. [http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/05/15/the-defenders-s-my-dad-says-and-mad-love-canceled-by-cbs/92704/ "The Defenders, S#*! My Dad Says and Mad Love Cancelled by CBS"] http://www.tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150317234421/http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/ |date=2015-03-17 }}. May 15, 2011</ref> She also starred in the indie satire ''[[Visioneers]]'' (2008).
[[File:Judy Greer LF.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Greer in 2008]] In April 2008, Greer appeared as a [[yoga]] instructor in the "[[Get a Mac]]" ad series featuring [[John Hodgman]] and [[Justin Long]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Foresman |first=Chris |url=https://arstechnica.com/apple/2008/04/new-get-a-mac-ads-feature-some-geek-chic-co-stars/ |title=New Get a Mac ads feature some geek chic co-stars |publisher=Ars Technica |date=2008-04-02 |accessdate=2013-01-17}}</ref> Greer starred in a [[CBS]] sitcom entitled ''[[Mad Love (TV series)|Mad Love]]'', which premiered in February [[2010–2011 United States network television schedule|2011]] as a mid-season replacement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/06/judy-greer-joins-cbs-comedy-mad-love-which-is-now-a-go-for-a-midseason-run/|title=Judy Greer Joins CBS' Comedy 'Mad Love,' Which Is Now A Go For A Midseason Run|date=June 26, 2010 |last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|publisher=Deadline.com|accessdate=June 28, 2010}}</ref> The show was canceled after the first season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/05/15/the-defenders-s-my-dad-says-and-mad-love-canceled-by-cbs/92704/ |title=The Defenders Cancelled by CBS; $#*! My Dad Says Cancelled by CBS; Mad Love Cancelled by CBS - Ratings | TVbytheNumbers |publisher=Tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com |date=2011-05-15 |accessdate=2013-01-17}}</ref>
[[File:Judy Greer, Comic-Con 2010.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Greer at [[San Diego Comic-Con International|Comic-Con International]] in July 2010]] Greer is also a voice actress, voicing the character of Cheryl on the animated comedy series ''[[Archer (2009 TV series)|Archer]]'', a character which has been compared to her role on ''Arrested Development'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.collider.com/2010/07/23/comic-con-archer-interviews-judy-greer-chris-parnell-adam-reed/ |title=SDCC 2010: ARCHER Interviews with Judy Greer, Chris Parnell, and Creator Adam Reed |accessdate=July 30, 2010 |last=Lasker |first=Jake |date=July 23, 2010 |publisher=Collider.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100726140124/http://www.collider.com/2010/07/23/comic-con-archer-interviews-judy-greer-chris-parnell-adam-reed |archivedate=July 26, 2010 |df= }}</ref> and the character of Wendy Park on the stop-motion animated sitcom ''[[Glenn Martin, DDS]]''.<ref name="goldman"/> Greer has also portrayed two characters on ''[[Two and a Half Men]]''; Bridget Schmidt the ex-wife of Walden Schmidt ([[Ashton Kutcher]]), and Myra Melnick, a love interest of [[Charlie Harper (Two and a Half Men)|Charlie Harper]] ([[Charlie Sheen]]) and the sister of Herb Melnick ([[Ryan Stiles]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/ae/tv/tvguide/article/Exclusive-Judy-Greer-to-Star-as-Ashton-Kutcher-s-2146393.php |title=Greer to star on Two and a Half Men |date=September 2, 2011 |last= |first= |publisher= |accessdate=August 29, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In November 2011, Greer was honored with the [[Independent Spirit John Cassavetes Award]] at the [[Denver Film Festival]], where two films featuring Greer were in the festival's programming, including a red carpet screening of [[Alexander Payne]]'s ''[[The Descendants]]'' and [[Jay Duplass|Jay]] and [[Mark Duplass]]' ''[[Jeff, Who Lives at Home]]''. She is the first actress to be honored with the award.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://movies.yahoo.com/news/evening-judy-greer-starz-denver-film-festival-162808816.html |title=An Evening With Judy Greer at Starz Denver Film Festival |date=November 4, 2011 |last=Cangialosi |first=Jason |publisher=Yahoo! Movies News |accessdate=November 8, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018205714/http://movies.yahoo.com/news/evening-judy-greer-starz-denver-film-festival-162808816.html |archivedate=October 18, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
In late 2012, Greer made her [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] debut playing Jenny in ''[[Dead Accounts]]'', a short-lived new comedy by [[Theresa Rebeck]] also starring [[Katie Holmes]], [[Norbert Leo Butz]], [[Jayne Houdyshell]] and [[Josh Hamilton (actor)|Josh Hamilton]].<ref>Judy Greer Biography on [http://broadway.com broadway.com]</ref>
She played the gym teacher [[Rita Desjardin|Miss Desjardin]] in the 2013 horror remake ''[[Carrie (2013 film)|Carrie]]'' alongside [[Chloë Grace Moretz]] and [[Julianne Moore]], and played female chimp Cornelia in ''[[Dawn of the Planet of the Apes]]'' (2014).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2013/03/judy-greer-dawn-of-the-planet-of-the-apes-cornelia.html |title=Exclusive: Judy Greer Joins Planet of the Apes -- Vulture|work=Vulture |accessdate=28 April 2016}}</ref> In 2014, Greer made her directorial debut, with a short film for [[AOL]], ''Quiet Time''.<ref name=glam/> Greer starred with [[Nat Faxon]] in the [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] comedy series ''[[Married (TV series)|Married]]'', which premiered in July 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vulture.com/2014/01/fx-orders-judy-greernat-faxon-series.html|title=FX Orders Judy Greer–Nat Faxon Series|date=2014-01-24|publisher=vulture.com|accessdate=August 28, 2014}}</ref>
In 2015, Greer co-starred in the films ''[[Tomorrowland (film)|Tomorrowland]]'', ''[[Jurassic World]]'' and ''[[Ant-Man (film)|Ant-Man]]'', among others.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/judy-greer-joins-jurassic-world-693459|title=Judy Greer Joins 'Jurassic World'|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter |date=|accessdate=2014-04-03}}</ref> In 2016, she debuted in the lead voice role of Beep in the [[Netflix]] children's animated programs, ''[[Ask the StoryBots]]'' and ''[[StoryBots Super Songs]]''. In 2017, she reprised her role as Cornelia in the film sequel ''[[War for the Planet of the Apes]]'',<ref name="Greer">{{cite web |url=http://hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/judy-greer-returning-planet-apes-833074 | title=Judy Greer Returning to "Planet of the Apes" (Exclusive) | work=The Hollywood Reporter | date=October 20, 2015 | accessdate=October 21, 2015 | last=Kit | first=Borys}}</ref> and in 2018, she again played her role as Maggie Lang, in the superhero film ''[[Ant-Man and the Wasp]]''. She then co-starred as Karen, the daughter of [[Laurie Strode]], in the 2018 horror sequel film ''[[Halloween (2018 film)|Halloween]]''.
Greer voices the titular character, Luna, in the animated television series ''[[Let's Go Luna!]]'', which premiered on November 21, 2018.
==Personal life== Greer is married to Dean E. Johnsen, an executive producer of ''[[Real Time with Bill Maher]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/actress-judy-greer-marries-dean-johnson-20111912|title=Actress Judy Greer Marries Dean Johnsen|author=Zach Johnson|date=December 19, 2011|publisher=usmagazine.com|accessdate=2012-02-01}}</ref> She is a stepmother to Johnsen's two children from his previous marriage.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://heavy.com/entertainment/2014/07/judy-greer-nat-faxon-married-fx/|title=Judy Greer: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know |work=Heavy.com|accessdate=13 September 2018}}</ref>
Greer grew up Catholic, although at the age of ten she convinced her parents to let her go to a Presbyterian church, claiming that she thought she would be closer to God there. The real reason was that she thought there were cuter boys at that church.<ref name="colbert2017"/> During a 2014 interview, Greer stated that she is no longer a practicing Catholic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://interviewly.com/i/judy-greer-apr-2014-reddit|title=Interviewly -Judy Greer April 2014 - reddit AMA|work=Interviewly|accessdate=28 April 2016}}</ref>
In 2014, she told ''[[Glamour (magazine)|Glamour]]'', "I had been wanting to try and learn how to meditate, and I did research on the different types of meditation. [[Transcendental Meditation technique|TM]] seemed the easiest, and I liked that it wasn't religious in any way."<ref name=glam>{{cite web|last=Radloff|first=Jessica|title=Judy Greer Has the Perfect Solution for Coping With Stress in Her New AOL Short|url=http://www.glamour.com/entertainment/blogs/obsessed/2014/05/judy-greer-has-the-perfect-sol.html|accessdate=14 May 2014|quote=Greer is adding director to her resume as she showcases why Transcendental Meditation has become such a huge part of her life.}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=September 2009}}
This is a list of '''last [[:wikt:scion|scion]]s''' or '''individuals who were the last member of a ruling house''', or other prominent family, where heredity is the prime form of inheritance. This may be the last person to rule a realm, sometimes leading to a political crisis, or a change in government; other times power has already passed from the patrilineal family, leaving it in a less important position when it reaches its extinction.
==House of Aviz== The [[House of Aviz]], an illegitimate branch of its predecessor the [[House of Burgundy]], ruled Portugal from 1385 to 1580; its last member was ''[[Henry, King of Portugal|Henrique, Cardinal-King of Portugal]]'' (1512–1580), who succeeded his grand-nephew [[Sebastian of Portugal|King Sebastian]] late in life. [[António, Prior of Crato]] would briefly rule Portugal shortly thereafter, but his illegitimate birth contests his claim to be considered a member of the House of Aviz.
==House of Bourbon (main line)== The main line of the [[House of Bourbon]], which had ruled France from 1589 to 1793 and from 1814 to 1830, became extinct with the death of ''[[Henri, comte de Chambord]]'' (1820–1883), grandson of [[Charles X of France|King Charles X]]. The comte de Chambord was the last male-line descendant of [[Louis XV of France|King Louis XV]], but many other lines of the house survive, including the [[Spanish Royal Family]], the [[Grand Ducal Family of Luxembourg]], and pretenders to the thrones of numerous other European thrones, all descending from [[Henry IV of France]] and ultimately from [[Hugh Capet]] of the [[House of Capet]].
==House of Bruce== The [[Clan Bruce]] ruled Scotland from 1306 to 1371. Its last royal member was ''[[David II of Scotland|King David II]]'' (1324–1371), upon whose death without issue the throne passed to his nephew [[Robert II of Scotland|Robert Stewart]]. The Clan continues today through other lines that do not have patrilineal royal ancestry, although the current clan chief, [[Andrew Bruce, 11th Earl of Elgin]], is descended from [[Robert I of Scotland|King Robert Bruce]] in the female line.
==<nowiki/>House of Burgundy (Portuguese branch)== A branch of the [[House of Burgundy]], itself a branch of the [[House of Capet]], was the first ruling house of the [[Kingdom of Portugal]] in 1139. Its last male member was ''[[Ferdinand I of Portugal|King Ferdinand I]]'' (1345–1383), whose daughter ''[[Beatrice of Portugal|Beatrice]]'' (1372–1408) was the disputed queen for two years, as well as [[List of Castilian consorts|queen of Castile and León by marriage]]. Instead Ferdinand's illegitimate half-brother [[John I of Portugal|John, Grand Master of the Order of Aviz]] became king, forming the [[House of Aviz]].
==House of Dunkeld== The last member of the [[House of Dunkeld]] was ''[[Alexander III of Scotland|King Alexander III]]'' (1241–1286), ending the family's rule over Scotland that had persisted since 1058. Alexander, the last male-line descendant of [[Duncan I of Scotland|King Donnchad I]], who ruled from 1034 to 1040, outlived his own children, leaving only his granddaughter (though his daughter) [[Margaret, Maid of Norway]] as heir; her death a few years later plunged Scotland into an interregnum.
==House of Habsburg== Male members of the [[House of Habsburg]] held many regnal titles in Europe from the twelfth to eighteenth centuries, most importantly those of [[Holy Roman Emperor]] (and its German associate and [[predecessor state|predecessor titles]]) and [[List of Spanish monarchs|King of Spain]]. Its last male scion was ''[[Charles VI, Holy Roman Emperor|Emperor Charles VI]]'' (1685–1740). His daughter ''[[Maria Theresa of Austria]]'' (1717–1780), who succeeded to some of her father's titles by inheritance and gained power of the rest of her father's domains when her husband was elected Emperor, was the last member of the royal house. Her descendants, the [[House of Lorraine]], continued to hold this power and were styled the House of Habsburg-Lorraine.
==House of Lancaster== The [[House of Lancaster]] or Lancaster branch of the [[House of Plantagenet]] ruled England from 1399 to 1461 and again briefly in 1470-1471; its last scion was ''[[Henry VI of England|King Henry VI]]'', who outlived his only son [[Edward of Westminster, Prince of Wales]]. Henry VI also had [[English claims to the French throne|claims to the French throne]] through the parentage of his mother [[Catherine of Valois]] and the conquests of his father [[Henry V of England|King Henry V]]. See also ''[[#Houses of Plantagenet and York|House of Plantagenet]]''.
==House of Luxembourg== Long before the present [[Grand Duchy of Luxembourg]] was established, the [[House of Luxembourg]] was a powerful family in Germany, supplying several [[Holy Roman Emperor]]s. The last of these was ''[[Sigismund, Holy Roman Emperor|Sigismund]]'' (1368–1437), also [[King of Hungary]] and [[King of Bohemia|Bohemia]]. His daughter ''[[Elisabeth of Bohemia (1409–1442)]]'' survived him to become the last Luxembourg family monarch, ruling Hungary and Bohemia and also as [[german Queen|German queen consort]]. A non-imperial branch of the House descended from [[Henry V, Count of Luxembourg]] ruled as French nobles until the death of [[Charles II, Duke of Brienne]] in 1608.
==House of Orange-Nassau== The [[House of Orange-Nassau]], which had ruled before the Napoleonic Wars as [[Prince of Orange|Princes of Orange]], served as [[Monarchy of the Netherlands|Kings of the Netherlands]] and [[List of Grand Dukes of Luxembourg|Grand Dukes of Luxembourg]] from 1815. [[King-Grand Duke]] ''[[William III of the Netherlands|William III]]'' (1817–1890), who outlived his three sons, was the last male member of the house and the last person to rule both countries; his daughter ''[[Wilhelmina of the Netherlands]]'' (1880–1962) succeeded him as Queen, while Luxembourg passed to the [[House of Nassau-Weilburg]]. The house became totally extinct in the male line with Wilhelmina's death, but the name is still used by her descendants, who continue to rule.
==Houses of Plantagenet and York== The last male member of the [[House of Plantagenet]], which ruled England from 1154 to 1485 and had fluctuating control over parts of [[France]], was ''[[Edward Plantagenet, 17th Earl of Warwick]]'' (1475–1499), a nephew of [[Edward IV of England|King Edward IV]] and great-great-grandson of [[Edward III of England|King Edward III]]. His uncle [[Richard III of England|King Richard III]] had been killed and replaced by [[Henry VII of England|Henry Tudor]], who started his own royal dynasty and eventually had Warwick executed. The last legitimate male-line descendant of [[Henry II of England]], first Plantagenet king, was Warwick's sister ''[[Margaret Pole, 8th Countess of Salisbury]]'' (1473–1541), who was executed by Henry Tudor's son [[Henry VIII of England|King Henry VIII]].
As descendants of the earliest [[Duke of York|Dukes of York]], Edward and Margaret may also be considered the last scions of the [[House of York]] or York branch of the House of Plantagenet, which ruled England specifically from 1461 to 1485 (with a brief pause in 1470-1471).
==House of Stuart== The last member of the [[House of Stuart]] was ''[[Henry Benedict Stuart]]'' (1725–1807), a [[Roman Catholic]] [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|cardinal]]. He was the last legitimate male-line descendant of [[Robert II of Scotland|Robert II]], who became [[List of Scottish monarchs|King of Scots]] in 1371. The House of Stuart had ruled [[Kingdom of Scotland|Scotland]] since then and [[Kingdom of England|England]] since 1603, replaced temporarily from 1649 to 1660 by the [[Covenanter]]s and permanently in 1714 when [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Queen Anne]] died without surviving children, although Henry Cardinal Stuart's grandfather [[James II of England|King James II & VII]] had been dethroned in 1688 during the [[Glorious Revolution]]. The headship of the house is usually associated today with [[Franz, Duke of Bavaria]] of the [[House of Wittelsbach]], the senior heir-general of James II & VII's sister [[Henrietta Anne Stuart|Henrietta Anna, Duchess of Orléans]]. Non-royal branches of the family still survive. The [[Earl of Galloway|Earls of Galloway]] are the senior surviving line of the Stuarts, they descend from a line which originated from the second son of [[Alexander Stewart, 4th High Steward of Scotland]].
==House of Tudor== The last male member of the [[Tudor dynasty|House of Tudor]], which had ruled England since 1485, was ''[[Edward VI of England|King Edward VI]]'' (1537–1553). His half-sister ''[[Elizabeth I of England|Queen Elizabeth I]]'' (1533–1603) took the throne in 1558 and ruled until her death, when the [[House of Stuart]] came to the throne in the person of [[James I of England|King James VI of Scotland]].
==House of York== :''See [[#Houses of Plantagenet and York|House of Plantagenet]].''
[[Category:Nobility]] [[Category:Lists of families|Last scions]]

page.title: List of people who remarried the same spouse

revision.text:
This is a '''list of people who remarried each other''', usually after divorcing. To qualify, at least one member of each marital pair must be considered notable enough to have their own Wikipedia page. Of particular note are: * [[Kid McCoy]], American prize fighter, who married and divorced ten times, but only from eight women, since '''three''' of those marriages were to the same spouse, Julia Woodruff * [[Richard Pryor]], American comedian and actor, who was twice divorced from both Jennifer Lee and Flynn Belaine * Joyce Mathews, American actress, who was twice divorced from both [[Milton Berle]] and [[Billy Rose]] {| Class="wikitable" ! Name ! Description ! Spouse ! 1st
marriage ! 1st divorce ! 2nd

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Mahjoub Tobji | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date ={{Birth year and age|1942}} | birth_place = [[Meknes]], [[Morocco]] | other_names = | occupation = Retired Moroccan army commandant | nickname = | allegiance = {{flagicon|Morocco}} Morocco |branch=[[File:Flag of the Royal Moroccan Army.svg|23px]] [[Royal Moroccan Army]] | serviceyears = 1960–2002 | rank = [[Commandant (rank)|Commandant]] |commands= |unit= |battles=[[Yom Kippur war]]
[[Western Sahara War]] }} '''Mahjoub Tobji''' ({{lang-ar|محجوب الطوبجي}}, born 1942 in [[Meknes]]) is a retired [[Commandant (rank)|Commandant]] of the [[Royal Moroccan Army]]. He commanded a battalion of [[Sahrawi people|Sahrawi]] soldiers during the [[Western Sahara war]] and was the [[Aide-de-camp]] of General [[Ahmed Dlimi]]. Upon the death of the latter he was arbitrarily detained during 20 months and was able escape prison and fled to France.{{cite news|language = fr|title = Détenu depuis vingt mois, l'ancien aide de camp du général Dlimi s'est évadé de sa prison|url = http://www.lemonde.fr/archives/article/1984/10/11/detenu-depuis-vingt-mois-l-ancien-aide-de-camp-du-general-dlimi-s-est-evade-de-sa-prison_3136438_1819218.html|journal = [[Le Monde]]|date= 11 October 1984}} He went back to Morocco after he succeeded in meeting [[Hassan II]] during his vacations in France at the Hotel Le Crillon.{{cite book|title=Les Officiers de Sa Majesté|date=2006|author=Mahjoub Tobji}} In 2005, he wrote a book ''({{lang-fr|Les Officiers de Sa Majesté}})'' about the Moroccan army and its operations during deployments in the [[Yom Kippur war]] and Western Sahara. In this book he singled out General [[Housni Benslimane]] as the most powerful man in Morocco, responsible for his imprisonment and other exactions against Moroccan dissidents which were blamed on [[Driss Basri]].{{cite news|title=Ahmed Dlimi. Pouvoir, luxure… et trahison ?|url=http://www.telquel-online.com/archives/396/couverture_396.shtml|accessdate=31 January 2014|newspaper=[[Telquel]]|date=N° 396|author=Fahd Iraqi|author2=Lahcen Aouad|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202101239/http://www.telquel-online.com/archives/396/couverture_396.shtml|archivedate=2 February 2014|df=}} After the publication of his book, he faced some intimidations in his exile in France. His pension was abruptly stopped in late 2012, and was only re-established after he went on a hunger-strike.{{cite news|last=Ghita Ismaili|title=France : Mahjoub Tobji, l’ancien militaire marocain, arrête sa grève de la faim|url=http://www.yabiladi.com/articles/details/17543/france-mahjoub-tobji-l-ancien-militaire.html|accessdate=31 January 2014|newspaper=Yabiladi|date=23 May 2013}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Human rights in Morocco}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tobji, Mahjoub}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:Moroccan Army officers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Meknes]] [[Category:Moroccan exiles]] [[Category:Moroccan expatriates in France]] [[Category:Moroccan writers in French]] [[Category:Moroccan prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:Moroccan escapees]] [[Category:Moroccan military officers]] [[Category:Moroccan whistleblowers]]

''{{Use Indian English|date=October 2015}}'' {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox saint |name = [[Canonizationtion|Blessed]]
Mariam Thresia of Chiramel Mankidiyan |image = Mariam Thresia - %E0%B4%AE%E0%B4%B1%E0%B4%BF%E0%B4%AF%E0%B4%82 %E0%B4%A4%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%B0%E0%B5%87%E0%B4%B8%E0%B5%8D%E0%B4%AF 15.JPG |imagesize = 200px |caption = |titles = Religious; Mystic |birth_date = 26 April 1876 |birth_place = [[Puthenchira]], [[Thrissur District]], [[Kerala]], [[India]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1926|06|08|1876|04|26|df=yes}} |death_place = Kuzhikattussery, Thrissur District, India |feast_day = 8 June |venerated_in = {{unbulleted list|[[Syro-Malabar Catholic Church|Syro-Malabar Church]]|[[Roman Catholic Church]]}} |beatified_date = 9 April 2000 |beatified_place = [[Saint Peter's Square]], [[Vatican City]] |beatified_by = [[Pope John Paul II]] |canonized_date = |canonized_place = |canonized_by = |major_shrine = |attributes = Religious habit |patronage = Congregation of the Holy Family |issues = |suppressed_date = }} [[Canonization|Blessed]] '''Thresia Chiramel Mankidiyan''' (usually known as '''Mariam Thresia'''; 26 April 1876 – 8 June 1926) was an [[Indian people|Indian]] [[Syro-Malabar Catholic Church|Syro-Malabar]] [[Nun|professed religious]] and the founder of the Congregation of the Holy Family.{{cite web|url=http://catholicsaints.info/blessed-mariam-thresia-chiramel-mankidiyan/|title=Blessed Mariam Thresia Chiramel Mankidiyan|publisher=Saints SQPN|date=4 June 2016|accessdate=11 October 2016}} Thresia Mankidiyan became known for receiving frequent visions and ecstasies as well as even receiving the [[stigmata]] which she kept well-guarded. She had been involved in apostolic work her entire life and pushed for strict adherence to the rule of her order amongst her fellow religious.{{cite web|url=http://www.vatican.va/news_services/liturgy/saints/ns_lit_doc_20000409_beat-Mankidiyan_en.html|title=Mariam Thresia Chiramel Mankidiyan (1876-1926)|date=|publisher=Holy See|accessdate=11 October 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://mariamthresia.org/|title=A Timeline of Bl. Mariam Thresia|date=|publisher=Bl. Mariam Thresia|accessdate=11 October 2016}} [[Pope John Paul II]] beatified the late nun on 9 April 2000. ==Life speech== Thresia Chiramel Mankidiyan was born in [[Puthenchira]] in the [[Thrissur district]] on 26 April 1876 as the third of five children of Thoma and Thanda and was later [[baptized]] on 3 May 1876 at the church of Saint Mary; she was named in honor of [[Teresa of Ávila|Saint Teresa of Ávila]]. Her paternal uncle Antony Chiramel Mankidiyan was her godfather and his wife Anna was the godmother. Her family was once rich though became poor when her grandfather married off seven daughters after selling property for each costly dowry; this led to her brothers and her father taking up drinking. Her mother was her father's second wife; her father's first wife Mariamkutty died during childbirth in 1872. She had two sisters and two brothers and were in exact order: Porinchu, Mariamkutty, Ouseph and Ittianam - she was born in between Mariamkutty and Ouseph. In 1884 her mother tried in vain to dissuade the pious girl from her severe fasts and night vigils. Her mother died on 2 March 1888 after blessing her children who gathered at her deathbed. Her mother's death marked the conclusion of her studies and she instead dedicated herself to contemplation in her local parish church. She made a private vow to remain chaste in 1886. In 1891 she hatched a scheme to sneak from home to lead a life of penance in the hills but soon decided against this and instead returned home. Since 1904 she desired to be called "Mariam" under the belief she had a vision from the [[Blessed Virgin Mary]] in which she was instructed to add it to her name. From 1902 to 1905 she was subjected to several exorcisms from [[Venerable]] [[Joseph Vithayathil]] - under the orders of the local bishop - and from 1902 it was Vithayathil who became her [[Spiritual direction|spiritual director]] until her death. In 1903 she requested Mar [[John Menachery]] - the [[Archbishop of Thrissur]] - to build a house of retreat but it was turned down. This happened after she had formed a group with three other friends and engaged in apostolic work with poor families. Menachery instead suggested she make an effort to join a religious congregation and encouraged her to join the new Congregation of the Franciscan Clarists but left since she didn't fell called to it. Mankidiyan later accepted the mar's request in 1912 to join the [[Carmelites]] at [[Ollur]] and was there since November 26, 1912 until she left on 27 January 1913 because she did not feel drawn to them either. In 1913 she set up a house at [[Puthenchira]] and on 14 May 1914 founded the Congregation of the Holy Family to which she was professed in and vested in its habit; she was the first superior of the order. She was said to have had a range of spiritual experiences such as receiving the [[stigmata]] and hid this from public view; she first had this in 1905 though became more visible on 27 January 1909. She also purportedly suffered a series of demonic attacks. In 1926 a falling object struck her on the leg and the wound soon festered. Mankidiyan was admitted to the local hospital though doctors deemed her condition fatal and she was moved by bullock cart back to her [[convent]] where on 7 June 1926 she received the final sacraments and the [[Viaticum]]. She died at 10:00pm on 8 June 1926 from her leg wound that her [[diabetes]] exacerbated. Her final words were: "[[Jesus Christ|Jesus]], Mary and [[Saint Joseph|Joseph]]; I give you my heart and my soul" - she then closed her eyes and died. On the morning of her death she was laid on the floor on a mat at her request with her spiritual director and fellow religious huddled around her. Her funeral was celebrated on 9 June and in accordance with her wishes her remains were not washed prior to her funeral. ==Beatification== The beatification process opened in [[Irinjalakuda]] on 12 July 1982 after the [[Congregation for the Causes of Saints|C.C.S (Congregation for the Causes of Saints)]] titled her as a [[Servant of God]] and issued the official "[[nihil obstat]]" (nothing against) to the cause while the cognitional process opened on 14 May 1983 and concluded its business on 24 September 1983; the C.C.S. later validated the process after its conclusion in [[Rome]] on 8 November 1985 and received the [[Positio]] dossier from the postulation a decade later in 1997. The board of historians met to assess the cause and to determine if historical obstacles existed before issuing their approval for the cause on 27 May 1997 at which point the theologians approved it on 9 October 1998 as did the C.C.S. on 19 April 1999. [[Pope John Paul II]] named the late religious as [[Venerable]] on 28 June 1999 after he confirmed that she had lived a life of [[heroic virtue]]. The investigation of the miracle required for beatification was held in the [[Trichur]] eparchy from 28 April 1992 to 26 July 1993 and was validated on 22 January 1999 before receiving the approval of the medical board on 16 November 1999. Theologians then voiced their own approval on 5 January 2000 . The miracle was that of the cure of one Mathew D. Pellissery, who was born in 1956 with congenital club feet. He could barely walk with great difficulty on the sides of his feet until he was fourteen. After 33 days of fasting and prayer by the whole family, invoking the help of Mariam Thresia, his right foot was straightened during sleep on the night of 21 August 1970. Similarly after 39 days of fasting and prayer his left foot was also straightened overnight during sleep on 28 August 1971. Since then, Mathew has been able to walk normally. This double healing was declared inexplicable in terms of medical science by as many as nine doctors in India and Italy and thus met the last canonical requirement for her beatification. It was declared a miracle obtained through the intercession of Mariam Thresia by the C.C.S. on 18 January 2000 before the Pope himself issued final approval on it on 27 January 2000. John Paul II beatified Mariam Thresia on 9 April 2000 in [[Saint Peter's Square]]. Mathew Pellissery was present there during the beatification ceremony at St. Peter's Square. The second miracle - and the one needed for her canonization - was investigated in the diocese of its origin and later received the formal validation of the C.C.S. in Rome on 24 June 2014. The miraculous healing of the child Christopher received approval from the medical board in Rome in March 2018 and theologians later confirmed it in October 2018. The current [[postulator]] for this cause is the [[Jesuit]] priest George Nedungatt. ==Media== ''Vaazhthappetta Mariam Thresia: Kudumbangalude Madhyastha'' directed by Sibi Yogyaveedan on [[Shalom (TV channel)]] won the award for the best teleserial at [[Kerala State Chalachitra Academy|Kerala State television awards]] for 2013.{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Thiruvananthapuram/state-television-awards-announced/article7128384.ece |title=State television awards announced - The Hindu |newspaper=Thehindu.com |date= |last= |accessdate=2017-12-27}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Maria Theresa Chiramel}} * [http://mariamthresia.com/ Official website] * {{YouTube|MAz9CsYdQ0Q}} * [http://newsaints.faithweb.com/year/1926.htm Hagiography Circle] * [http://catholicsaints.faithweb.com/blessed-mariam-thresia-chiramel-mankidiyan/ Saints SQPN] * [http://www.vatican.va/news_services/liturgy/saints/ns_lit_doc_20000409_beat-Mankidiyan_en.html Holy See] * [http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/90017 Santi e Beati] {{Christianity in Kerala|state=collapsed}} {{Canonization}} {{Subject bar |portal1= Biography |portal2= Catholicism |portal3= Saints|portal4= India}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chiramel, Maria Theresa}} [[Category:1876 births]] [[Category:1926 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century Indian women]] [[Category:19th-century Christian mystics]] [[Category:20th-century venerated Christians]] [[Category:20th-century Indian women]] [[Category:20th-century Christian mystics]] [[Category:Beatifications by Pope John Paul II]] [[Category:Roman Catholic mystics]] [[Category:Venerated Catholics from Kerala]] [[Category:Indian beatified people]] [[Category:Indian Christian mystics]] [[Category:Malayali people]] [[Category:Christian clergy from Thrissur]] [[Category:Stigmatics]] [[Category:Syro-Malabar Catholics]] [[Category:Venerated Catholics by Pope John Paul II]] [[Category:Women from Kerala]]

revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=January 2013}} '''Martha Mason''' (May 31, 1937 – May 4, 2009)<ref name=NYTObit>{{cite news|title=Martha Mason, Who Wrote Book About Her Decades in an Iron Lung, Dies at 71|first=Margalit|last=Fox|date=May 9, 2009|accessdate=May 10, 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/10/us/10mason.html}}</ref> was a writer born and based in [[Lattimore, North Carolina]] who spent 61 years in an [[Negative pressure ventilator|iron lung]].
==Early life== Afflicted with [[polio]] at age eleven during the epidemic of 1948, Mason was sent home from the hospital in an [[Negative pressure ventilator|iron lung]], in which she remained for the rest of her life. She preferred the iron lung to newer ventilators as it did not require [[intubation]], surgery, or hospitalization. Her brother, Gaston Mason, died of polio and it was only a few days after his funeral that her own polio symptoms began.
She completed high school with daily visits from her teachers, and graduated first in her class with highest honors.
Mason moved to [[Boiling Springs, NC|Boiling Springs]] with her parents to enroll in [[Gardner-Webb University|Gardner-Webb College]] (now University), earning an associate degree at age 21. She then attended (again with her parents' accompaniment) [[Wake Forest University|Wake Forest College]] (also now University), earning a bachelor's degree in English in 1960. She was first in her classes at both colleges. She received an honorary doctorate from Gardner-Webb University in May 2004.
After her education, Mason returned to Lattimore and started work at a local newspaper; her mother took dictation of her work. Shortly after, her father was incapacitated by a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] and her mother was unable to assist her in her work.
==Later life== Mason returned to writing in the mid 1990s when advancements in [[speech recognition]] technology enabled her to operate a computer on her own, giving her the ability to dictate and edit, as well as to browse the [[Internet]].
This latter factor was particularly significant for Mason. While her highly social and independent lifestyle (she hosted dinner parties and managed her own household, for example) would probably have only been possible in a tight-knit community (Lattimore's current population is approximately 400), her broad interests were not in tune with small-town perspectives.
She wrote a memoir, ''Breath: Life in the Rhythm of an Iron Lung'', which was published in 2003. She was also the subject of ''Martha in Lattimore'' (2005), a [[documentary film]] by Mary Dalton. Mason also appeared in the [[Academy Award|Oscar]]-nominated documentary about polio ''[[The Final Inch]]'' (2009).
==Death== She died in Lattimore shortly after dawn on Monday, May 4, 2009, one month shy of her 72nd birthday. She had lived 61 years in an iron lung before her death, longer than any other polio survivor in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/shelbystar/obituary.aspx?n=martha-mason&pid=126950930&fhid=7697|title=Martha Mason's Obituary on Shelby Star|website=Shelby Star|accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{IMDb title|0819663|Martha in Lattimore}} *{{IMDb title|1360061|The Final Inch}}
{{Authority control}}
